TEXT: My recent experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) was nothing short of frustrating. From the airline to the moment I arrived, the service was abysmally slow, and the staff was unhelpful. Immigration staff, in particular, were rude and disrespectful, making an already stressful experience far worse. The flight was plagued with significant delays, and constant gate changes, making the entire experience chaotic. The in-flight safety video was unprofessional and disturbing, especially for young passengers. This attempt at engagement was tasteless and unnecessary. Additionally, the constant gate changes and flight delays created confusion and anxiety throughout my entire time at the airport. Having to take a bus between terminals was highly inconvenient and only added to the frustration. What really stood out was the slogan displayed upon arrival: We hope youve enjoyed our Malaysian Hospitality. Frankly, this felt more like an empty promise than a reflection of the experience I had. A service should speak for itself, but in this case, it was clear that overcompensating with slogans only highlights the gap between what is advertised and what is actually delivered. Given this experience, I will never fly with Malaysian Airlines or visit Malaysia again and I certainly won't be encouraging my friends or family to visit.

TEXT: Ive traveled through KLIA countless times, and it has always impressed me with its cleanliness, smooth check-in process, and efficient security checks. The architecture, inspired by Malaysian, Islamic, and natural elements, remains a stunning highlight. But what truly made KLIA special was its balance of international and uniquely local offerings- something that now seems to be fading. With the recent KLIA1 renovation, I have to give credit where its due- the new bathrooms are a huge improvement! Well designed, good ventilation, clean and dry. But the retail and dining experience has taken a disappointing turn. Many local options have disappeared, replaced by foreign goods. And once again, alcohol and tobacco seem to dominate the retail spacewhy so much of it? I was shocked to find just one shelf of Malaysian food products in the entire terminal 1. Malaysia is a food paradisewhy isnt KLIA celebrating this? Instead, the vibrancy of local flavors is being replaced by the bland sameness of foreign coffe chains, croissants, and cakes. More AUTHENTIC local options would be a delight!- especially for those leaving home and craving one last nasi lemak or kuey teow or teh tarik or curried roti? Once, travelers could enjoy authentic Malaysian dishes like kaya toast, prawn noodles, and teh tarik. Now, the F&B scene is overrun by global chains like Starbucks and Gloria Jeans. Surely, KLIA can do better by making space for homegrown eateries that showcase Malaysias rich culinary diversity?- take a page out of Jakarta or Singapore airport. To add to the frustration, the monorail is still out of service (Ive lost count how long Ive waited), forcing travelers to rely on slow and inefficient shuttle buses. And when I asked an Ask Me For Help staff member for food recommendations, she barely looked up from her phone. Customer service should be better than this! KLIA, lets do better! Support local businesses and bring back the authentic Malaysian experience to travellers. P.S. if youre ever at the Satellite building of KLIA terminal 1 (after the shuttle service), I highly recommend visiting the Jungle Boardwalk - a small beautiful green forest in the middle of the building I always look forward to visiting it if my Gate is located there.

TEXT: Edit:DO NOT USE GRAB ehailing, especially advance booking. You'll get the most greedy and unfriendly driver ever. Use BOLT. Your welcome for cheaper ride. bypass airport expensive surcharge by using trains. Use the ERL and drop off at Salak Tinggi. And you can get cheaper ehailing ride. Dear traveler, do NOT use "taxi" that waiting at the airport. They "offer" you a ride for rm300-400. You should only get a ride via ehailing service, I recommended BOLT. A ride from airport to Kuala Lumpur should not exceed RM80, MAX. If a 4 seats it RM50 MAX. If you book an ehailing, driver can't ask more money from you. Pay what in the app. If driver ask for more money, record them & car number plate, and go to police station to submit a report. Those driver who doesn't use the app / ask for more money is the betrayal to Malaysia.

TEXT: I had the worst experience in this airport for travelling. This looks fancy but very old school. Restaurant not enough air con at night time. Sweating when eating Very confusing direction or procedure. I was required to transferred here from overseas to KKIA (domestic) i was not required to take my lugguage while I gone through the customs here. Then walked all the way from international to domestic from the international building. But then I was required to "enter" the Malaysia border again while I was in KKIA (I took domestic) with my checked in luggage and scanning my index fingers When i went back from KK to KL, I only required to go thru the custom once at KKIA. I was expecting to go thru the domestic building so I can get some local products. Then my hand luggage was required to go thru x ray just at the gate. My flask was full of water. But it was not required to empty out. And no airline staff at the gate just b4 boarding to check the boarding priority. As I thought I can walk thru, so I followed the sign. I realised I couldn't walk thru after 5 mins later. Then I walked back and realised the sign was directed incorrectly neat gate G section. One pointing left and the other sign pointed right. TEXT: It's a gigantic airport, but unlike other mega-airports, it's not easy to find your way around. Fortunately, the police and airport staff are very friendly and helpful. But you have to be prepared for time and take things slowly. To board a domestic flight from an international airport, it took us almost an hour, including the transfer (by bus), then the elevator, then reprinting the boarding pass (because the previous one no longer worked), then finding the domestic flight exit, then going through carry-on baggage control (you have to remove all electronic devices from your backpack, unlike at other airports where they are checked inside your luggage). In a word, take your time and take your time!

TEXT: Exhausting.. you need to have at least a year of airport work experience to just transit through this airport. It took nearly 2 hrs from landing to sitting down at our gate. So much is automated, and very few staff members to help, so when something goes wrong - like when the self bag-drop off machine stops working.. with one of our bags halfway through the conveyor, we were left for ages, not knowing what to do. So many more hurdles to jump such as filling in an MDAC, yes, we were asked to fill it in on-line at Siem Reap, but thought it couldn't possibly be for us as so many 'mandatory' boxes were irrelevant to us. However, at the airport, they insisted we filled it in with a bunch of false information, i.e. the address where we would be staying (had to put in an they address provided.. which was the airport's address) a waste of time, as we felt we could miss our connecting flight. We also had to create our own baggage tags, then TWO separate baggage screenings - so unnecessary. So many options of queues without clear instructions, so many people, so much walking - it just seemed chaotic. It's not my favourite airport. If we weren't so tired.. we had been travelling all day, I would have said a pretty average airport.

TEXT: Average airport, but pricey. Coffee, sandwich, travel necessities - be prepared to pay more. 2 coffees plus 2 sandwiches equaled almost RM120. At least there are some dispensers for free water. Boarding is very slow due to extra security checks at the gates. Plan at least another 30-40 minutes (the difference between the boarding time on your ticket vs the actual boarding time) for this second and very slow check. Once youre through this gate security check, theres a waiting area with no toilets and no water. So please take care is your needs BEFORE queueing for the gate security check. Second, the gate security check is hyper sensitive. My wifes passport - which she held in her hand - triggered it. They make you take off shoes and belts if those contain small metal bits. My empty laptop backpack went through the scanner twice and I have no idea why

TEXT: Unfortunately, my experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport was disappointing. Here are a few points that struck me negatively: 1. Strict baggage control, but not consistent: My hand luggage was accurately weighed, and even though it was only slightly over 7kg, I was told to pay extra. At the same time, the Malaysian woman in front of me, weighing almost 8 kg, was allowed to walk away - that felt unfair. 2. Poor Signage: Some gates had no numbers, which was extremely confusing. It was difficult to find the right path. 3. Lack of seating: There were no seats at the gate, which made the wait unnecessarily tiring. 4. Inadequate Toilets: The women's restrooms were a mess - I waited in line for over 30 minutes and when it was finally my turn, they were dirty. The men apparently had enough toilets as there were no queues. Unfortunately, the airport was the worst I've ever been to.

TEXT: Exactly about a week ago, when I was returning to my country from KLIA 1, I had an unpleasant experience with the X-ray staff at the gate, who had no manners! After that, I saw a water dispenser before entering the gate. I filled it up there... But as I was about to enter the gate, the unmannered officer yelled at me and told me to throw the water in the toilet, using a rude tone! And even worse, when I threw the water in the toilet, my mother was also scolded by the X-ray staff... Crazy, they really have no manners towards their elders! If drinks aren't allowed in the waiting room, please provide them in the waiting room... Are your airport staff going to take responsibility if we get thirsty? The airport has the worst and strangest regulations I've ever visited... So different from Singapore, Indonesia, and Thailand! Euwwwwww

TEXT: KLIA2 is by far the most disappointing terminal, starting with the immigration service, which completely kills any desire to ever return here. Weve been to Malaysia many times, arriving through KLIA, but weve never seen such chaos. Over 300 people in line, and only 8 counters open - and working incredibly slowly! We waited in line for 1.5 (!) hours. Whats the point of filling out the online arrival form if immigration officers still spend 4-7 minutes on each tourist? After standing in line for over 1.5 hours and watching how the officers worked, we were left very disappointed. Even worse was how immigration officers treated Asian travelers with darker skin - their gestures were so disrespectful, it was truly unpleasant to witness. Ah, yes! And before departure immigration process took 30 minutes at 6:30am. A reasonable processing time at passenger-respecting airports around the world is 1520 minutes. But not at KLIA2 - here, the staff act like theyre doing you a favor by letting you enter or leave the country. What a shame!

TEXT: My recent experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) was nothing short of frustrating. From the airline to the moment I arrived, the service was abysmally slow, and the staff was unhelpful. The immigration officers are rude and disrespectful, making an already stressful experience far worse. To be honest, it felt like the staff were completely uninterested in their job, and some even seemed to resent being there. When my family arrived at the immigration counter, the officer seemed confused when we asked whether he wanted to see our MDAC or passports first. He glanced at our passports and then repeatedly said, "You dont look British." When we asked why he was being rude, he flew into a rage and yelled, "What do you mean I am being rude! Youre not welcome here. Go back to where you came from." At first, I thought I could be overreacting, but as the situation unfolded, it made me wonder if this could be a case of racial bias, especially toward darker-skinned people. Its hard not to perceive this as racism when the treatment felt so harsh and unwarranted. But then, a white female tourist recounted her own experience, and she was visibly shaken, nearly on the verge of tears. She too had been yelled at and bullied by the Malaysian airport staff. To make matters worse, I also witnessed an Indian woman being denied entry to the bathroom just to retrieve her bag. After numerous attempts she managed to get them back. This made me realize that it wasnt just about skin colourthough it was hard not to make that connectionbut rather a broader issue with the staffs attitude toward tourist and travellers. The customer service here has drastically declined. This used to be a place where visitors were welcomed with warmth and respect, but unfortunately, thats no longer the case. Its a shame to see such a decline. In Malaysia, government jobs, including those at airports prioritize ethnic Malays over Indian and Chinese Malays. As a result, some government positions, such as immigration officers or airport staff, may be filled based on ethnicity rather than merit or qualifications. Due to this, individuals in these roles might lack the necessary qualifications or passion for the job, which can sometimes be reflected in their job performance and attitude. What really stood out was the slogan displayed upon arrival: We hope youve enjoyed our Malaysian Hospitality. Frankly, this felt more like an empty promise than a reflection of the experience I had. A service should speak for itself, but in this case, it was clear that overcompensating with slogans only highlights the gap between what is advertised and what is actually delivered. Given this experience, I will never fly with Malaysian Airlines or visit Malaysia again and I certainly won't be encouraging my friends or family to visit. Avoid countries that do not respect and appreciate tourist coming to help their economy!

TEXT: Dear Airport Authority, I am writing to formally express my disappointment regarding my experience at KLIA 2 on 28 January 2025 at 3:38 AM while waiting for the departure hall to open. One of your customer service staff (a Chinese male) informed us that the hall would open at 3:00 AM. However, when the hall was still closed at 3:10 AM, we asked another staff member (a Malay female), who then told us it would open at 4:00 AM. When we mentioned that her colleague had stated an earlier opening time, her response was: "Then you ikut apa yang dia cakap lah." When we further inquired about the actual opening time, she dismissively said: "Then you tunggu hall buka lah." I find this attitude highly unprofessional and unacceptable, especially for airport staff who are expected to assist passengers courteously. Providing inconsistent information and responding rudely to simple inquiries only creates confusion and frustration. I urge you to look into this matter and ensure that staff are properly trained to handle customer queries in a respectful and professional manner. Additionally, clear and accurate information regarding the departure hall opening time should be provided to avoid unnecessary inconvenience for passengers. I appreciate your prompt attention to this issue and look forward to your response.

TEXT: This airport made me never want to come back to Malaysia. Who designed this place?! First, the walk from the plane to immigration and baggage claim was unbelievably long. Ive traveled through many large airports, but Ive never had to walk this much just to reach my luggage. I could overlook that but what came next was even worse. After collecting our bags and passing immigration, we were forced to walk through (GET THIS!) A MALL to get to the exit. Yes, a literal mall where every airport in the world you'd be checking your transportation to finally leave. After a long flight, the last thing anyone wants is to be dragged through a maze of stores just to leave the airport. It felt like a cash grab, not a travel hub. We finally made it out and were relieved to see Grab was available (were used to it from Thailand). But when we booked a ride, the wait time was 35 minutes! There was a huge, overcrowded Grab waiting area with screens showing incoming car plates, clearly, demand was way beyond what the airport could handle. Tired and frustrated, we gave up on Grab, hoping to catch a bus instead. But we werent allowed to buy tickets until exactly 12 AM, which was also the listed departure time of the bus, because it's too late now to buy tickets (15 minutes ahead). We were told the bus would leave even after 12. The whole thing felt disorganized and unclear and the wait time seemed same as the Grab and the destination station is not even close to the hotel. In the end, we paid over double the Grab fare to take a regular taxi, just to get the hell out of there. Oh and did I mention that the airport wifi is not available once you finish immigration? I had such a hard time to book the Grab and check information and chat with my airbnb host because there was no wifi after immigration, because there's a freakin' mall between the airport and the exits!!! This airport is a logistical mess and a terrible first impression of Malaysia. I've never thought an airport would affect my will to visit a country but here we are.

TEXT: It's a gigantic airport, but unlike other mega-airports, it's not easy to find your way around. Fortunately, the police and airport staff are very friendly and helpful. But you have to be prepared for time and take things slowly. To board a domestic flight from an international airport, it took us almost an hour, including the transfer (by bus), then the elevator, then reprinting the boarding pass (because the previous one no longer worked), then finding the domestic flight exit, then going through carry-on baggage control (you have to remove all electronic devices from your backpack, unlike at other airports where they are checked inside your luggage). In a word, take your time and take your time!

TEXT: KLIA is an international airport that always feels like a poor budget airport that is falling apart. Ironically, it is overstaffed by an army of smiling greeters. On Sunday, 22 June 2025, we saw water dispenser stations broken and unrepaired. "Free drinks" stations abandoned, unmanned. The only smoking room in the airport is a filthy room covered in black soot: incredibly smelly, no ventilation systems, piles of ash, trash, and butts all over. Warning: Enter at your own risk. The aerotrain was being repaired, and although bus services were provided, no signs were available to passengers on where it is. Bus services from the sub terminal to the main terminal were not easy to find. Tragically, the contrast between KLIA and KLIA2 (the latter an actual budget terminal that's well designed, modern, clean, and efficient) has never been clearer.

TEXT: This was by far the worst and most unacceptable experience Ive ever had with any airline. At the Batik Air baggage counter in Kuala Lumpur before flight OD171 to Denpasar, I was shouted at, threatened, and pressured into paying a baggage fee of 650 MYR, with the amount changing several times without explanation. First it was more, then less, then suddenly 650 it was chaotic and clearly unprofessional. The staff member at the baggage scale used aggressive language, raised their voice, and intimidated me in front of other passengers. I felt unsafe and coerced. This was not a normal excess baggage fee it felt like extortion. I complied because I felt I had no choice. This is absolutely not the standard I expect from any airline, especially not from Batik Air, which previously had my trust. I have filed a formal complaint with the airline and am awaiting a refund and investigation. I strongly warn other travelers: If youre flying from Kuala Lumpur with Batik Air, be cautious at the baggage counter. Keep records, film interactions, and dont let yourself be bullied.

TEXT: The KLIA T2 airport is new, but design and service are not international standard. First of all: there are at least 4 checks after check in: first security check is to check your passport and boarding pass, then first (preliminary) baggage check. Then you go for normal immigration check. Dont relax there as closer to your gate wing there is a proper security check. The wings are very very long, so is 8000 steps by the time of boarding. There not enough female toilet: queue in each of 2 in my wing were 20+ females. If you arrive to terminal 2 there is another issue, they dont allow trolleys from the plane arrival gate to the exit from the airport, I had to change trolley twice: I e I used 3 trolleys. Immigration queue - 1 hour. There is no green and red corridor in customs, all luggage goes through screening. All shopping split in zones between all these 4 checks. Flying via KL is cheap but service is cheap too

TEXT: I had an extremely disappointing experience at Malaysias Airport Terminal 2. It was overcrowded with long lines, and the staff was not only unhelpful but also rude. One of the officers took my Dior and Chanel perfumes, which were under 100ml and purchased from duty-free, claiming they were not allowed. He kept them in his pocket without any proper explanation. In addition, he confiscated all of my expensive purchases and seemed greedy and unprofessional, as though he had never seen such items before. He even pressured me by asking, Do you want to catch your flight or not? This made me feel very intimidated, especially since I was traveling alone. Furthermore, although I was allowed 7kgs in check-in, the lady at the counter charged me approximately 130 RM for an extra weight charge, despite my prior allowance. I tried explaining the situation, but she ignored me. I would not recommend anyone visit Malaysia based on this experience. The way they treat tourists is appalling, and I felt threatened and mistreated. Shame on Malysians !

TEXT: I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines. While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, I was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight. Although the airport is large and packed with many shops and eateries, there are a few areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving passengers. These include clearer directional signs and more readily available information. Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member to go to C15 for a transfer to the arrival hall. The signage for this transfer was unclear, and it took us a while to find the area just to queue for a feeder bus. Would also suggest considering adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay. Since this airport is named as an international airport, wouldnt it be better to have basic international standard too? The situation worsened upon arrival at the arrival hall. The area was extremely crowded,people are in queue of 2 -3 lines in a row....resulting in a queue of over an hour just to clear immigration. Very disorganized and messy, no one was there to direct the human traffic which leads to all these mess. After clearing immigration, locating the correct baggage belt was challenging. The area was crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts where you needed to walk near the belt to check on the medium-sized monitor screen showing which flight these belts are meant for. The screen flashed so fast with so many people trying to catch a glimpse of the information, which was rather frustrating, especially when everyone was looking for the right belt for their luggage. Literally, many passengers were visibly struggling to find their luggage, moving up and down, left and right. We only found our luggage outside the luggage belt area, where there was a sign with the Singapore Airlines logo on the floor. Quite a handful of luggage was located there, which obviously most of those taking the same flight were still stuck in immigration. Imagine the time taken from the moment we disembark from the plane and just to get out until our luggage was left outside and not at the belt. Navigating the airport area to find a Grab was also confusing due to the signage much of which was in Malay. This can be rather challenging, especially after a series of such "events" we went through. We thought maybe this is common for arrival passengers to encounter, who knows we must go through the same things going back. On our return flight, we were once again required to take a short bus to the departure hall. Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient.We have to endure our thirst till our flight take off. As a tourist, I dont enjoy it if I have to go through so much hassle just to travel. Who doesnt want hassle-free travel? For the sake of everyone, I hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements.
processed_text: write provide feedback recent experience fly via singapore airline generally appreciate quality service singapore airline flight disappoint airport experience especially consider budget flight although airport large pack many shop eatery area could improve facilitate smooth transit arrive passenger include clear directional sign readily available information upon arrival disembark plane direct staff member go c15 transfer arrival hall signage transfer unclear take u find area queue feeder bus would also suggest consider adjust volume announcement speaker loud clear information english chinese malay since airport name international airport wouldnt good basic international standard situation worsen upon arrival arrival hall area extremely crowdedpeople queue 2 3 line rowresulting queue hour clear immigration disorganized messy one direct human traffic lead mess clear immigration locate correct baggage belt challenge area crowd three four luggage belt need walk near belt check mediumsized monitor screen show flight belt mean screen flash fast many people try catch glimpse information rather frustrate especially everyone look right belt luggage literally many passenger visibly struggle find luggage move leave right find luggage outside luggage belt area sign singapore airline logo floor quite handful luggage locate obviously take flight still stick immigration imagine time take moment disembark plane get luggage leave outside belt navigate airport area find grab also confuse due signage much malay rather challenge especially series event go think maybe common arrival passenger encounter know must go thing go back return flight require take short bus departure hall furthermore water dispenser available pass inspection gate inconvenientwe endure thirst till flight take tourist dont enjoy go much hassle travel doesnt want hasslefree travel sake everyone hope feedback take consideration future improvement

TEXT: Honestly, if you are of African, Chinese, Philippines, Indian, Bengali, Nepalese, any south or south east Asian country think twice before boarding a plane to tour Malaysia or to transiting at Kula Lumpur airport. If you had a good time at this airport, great. If you didn't, avoid it in the future. The officers that work here are nothing more than poor uneducated people given jobs because they are Muslim Malays. If you are travelling alone they will judge you based on your colour and ethnicity. I have learnt that a lot of bullying and physical assualt are subjected to people of Bengali, Burmese, Nepalese or sub continent backgrounds. This was specifically from a foreign worker and have verified a lot of similar cases from trip advisor. I had a friend who witnessed a group of 3-4 female Malaysian officers trying to steal the bag of an Indian girl of Aus/US/UK (can't tell the exact accent) nationality. I have also seen people get shouted and others being hit! Like what the hell! I have never seen such uncivilised behaviour at an international airport, and I have been to numerous airports across Asia and the middle east. A lot of Malaysian officers are also thieves. Be careful. I have heard of several incidents where they target individuals travelling alone, in pairs or in small groups getting pulled aside, physically hit and having money taken unlawfully from them. Though I'm not surprised. It's a Muslim majority country. Usually these people tout about honesty and peace but actually are the polar opposite rude, violent and openly steal. Like I said, if you are from an African, south or south east Asian background (note specifically not nationality but background) don't bother even going through the airport let alone holidaying here. Spend your hard earned money elsewhere.

TEXT: Edit: bypass airport expensive surcharge by using trains. Use the ERL and drop off at Salak Tinggi. And you can get cheaper ehailing ride. TEXT: This airport made me never want to come back to Malaysia. Who designed this place?! First, the walk from the plane to immigration and baggage claim was unbelievably long. Ive traveled through many large airports, but Ive never had to walk this much just to reach my luggage. I could overlook that but what came next was even worse. After collecting our bags and passing immigration, we were forced to walk through (GET THIS!) A MALL to get to the exit. Yes, a literal mall where every airport in the world you'd be checking your transportation to finally leave. After a long flight, the last thing anyone wants is to be dragged through a maze of stores just to leave the airport. It felt like a cash grab, not a travel hub. We finally made it out and were relieved to see Grab was available (were used to it from Thailand). But when we booked a ride, the wait time was 35 minutes! There was a huge, overcrowded Grab waiting area with screens showing incoming car plates, clearly, demand was way beyond what the airport could handle. Tired and frustrated, we gave up on Grab, hoping to catch a bus instead. But we werent allowed to buy tickets until exactly 12 AM, which was also the listed departure time of the bus, "because it's too late now to buy tickets" (15 minutes ahead). We were told the bus would leave even after 12. The whole thing felt disorganized and unclear and the wait time seemed same as the Grab and the destination station is not even close to the hotel. In the end, we paid almost triple the Grab fare to take a regular taxi, just to get the hell out of there. And also, the airport wifi is not available once you finish immigration! I had such a hard time to book the Grab taxi and check information and chat with my airbnb host because there was no wifi after immigration, in any airport that's when wifi is needed!! But here there's a freakin' mall between the airport and the exits!!! I've never had this much hastle and wasted time to manage to exit an airport. This airport is a logistical mess and a terrible first impression of Malaysia. I've never thought an airport would affect my will to visit a country but here we are.

TEXT: Ive traveled through KLIA countless times, and it has always impressed me with its cleanliness, smooth check-in process, and efficient security checks. The architecture, inspired by Malaysian, Islamic, and natural elements, remains a stunning highlight. But what truly made KLIA special was its balance of international and uniquely local offerings- something that now seems to be fading. With the recent KLIA1 renovation, I have to give credit where its due- the new bathrooms are a huge improvement! Well designed, good ventilation, clean and dry. But the retail and dining experience has taken a disappointing turn. Many local options have disappeared, replaced by foreign goods. And once again, alcohol and tobacco seem to dominate the retail spacewhy so much of it? I was shocked to find just one shelf of Malaysian food products in the entire terminal 1. Malaysia is a food paradisewhy isnt KLIA celebrating this? Instead, the vibrancy of local flavors is being replaced by the bland sameness of foreign caf chains, croissants, and cakes. More AUTHENTIC local options would be a delight!- especially for those leaving home and craving one last nasi lemak or kuey teow or teh tarik or curried roti? Once, travelers could enjoy authentic Malaysian dishes like kaya toast, prawn noodles, and teh tarik. Now, the F&B scene is overrun by global chains like Starbucks and Gloria Jeans. Surely, KLIA can do better by making space for homegrown eateries that showcase Malaysias rich culinary diversity?- take a page out of Jakarta or Singapore airport. To add to the frustration, the monorail is still out of service (Ive lost count how long Ive waited), forcing travelers to rely on slow and inefficient shuttle buses. And when I asked an Ask Me For Help staff member for food recommendations, she barely looked up from her phone. Customer service should be better than this! KLIA, lets do better! Support local businesses and bring back the authentic Malaysian experience to travellers. P.S. if youre ever at the Satellite building of KLIA terminal 1, I highly recommend checking out the Jungle Boardwalk I always look forward to visiting it if my Gate is located there.

TEXT: One of the worst airports I've ever been to. The staff is incredibly nonchalant, more busy checking their phones than helping passengers in difficulty. We arrived 30 minutes before boarding, but the agent at the counter categorically refused to let us through. He didn't even bother to call the gate to let us know we were there or try to find a solution. I know you have to arrive 1 hour before check-in and 30 minutes before boarding, but this was truly exceptional. Background: Our first flight (with Air Asia) was delayed by 1 hour, which left us only 45 minutes to check in for our second flight (with Malaysia Airlines). And in those 45 minutes, we had to: exit immigration, fill out immigration paperwork, take a taxi (because the train between the terminals was closed), go through customs again in the other terminal, and then take another bus to get to the plane, which is impossible to do in 45 minutes. Changing terminals was a real nightmare: the train connecting the terminals was out of service, so we had to retrace our steps to catch a taxi, which we had to pay for ourselves at a reception deskwhere, once again, the staff seemed more engrossed in their phones than in their work. After the first agent refused, we tried our luck at another check-in kiosk (using a machine); other people were there. We explained the situation, and to get through, we had to lie by saying that "the man at the counter had given us the green light." At that point, we were let through. Immigration and customs literally told us to run! But when we arrived at the boarding gate, just a minute before departure, they categorically refused to let us board. The staff were there, on their phones, with no desire to help. One woman even pretended to call someone to tell us that "it's over, the doors are closed," before literally turning her back on us. All this because of a delay by one of their partner airlines, and there was no flexibility, no consideration. The result: we had to buy new tickets, this time with Emirates. And there, however, nothing to complain abouttop-notch welcome, professional service.

TEXT: I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines. While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, I was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight. Although the airport is large and packed with many shops and eateries, there are a few areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving passengers. - These include having clearer directional signs/ large screen and more readily available information. Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member..standing at the side, to go to Cxx for a transfer to the arrival hall. - Wouldn't it be better to put up clear large signage at both sides of the walkway while we disembarked? - Would also suggest considering adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay. The signage for this bus transfer was also unclear, and it took us a while to find the area just to queue for a feeder bus. Since this airport is named as an international airport, wouldnt it be better to have a basic international standard too? Not sure if the timing we arrived is a peak season but that day itself,the no.of passengers is not a joke. The situation worsened upon arrival at the arrival hall. The area was extremely crowded, and people are in queue of 2 -3 lines in a row....resulting in a queue of over an hour just to clear immigration. Very disorganized and messy, no one was there to manage the human traffic, which leads to all these mess. Good thing is the officer trying their level best to clear the queue. After clearing immigration, locating the correct baggage belt was another challenge. The area was so crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts where you are required to walk near the belt to check on the monitor screen showing which flight these belts are meant for. The screen flashed so fast with so many people trying to catch a glimpse of the information, which was rather frustrating, especially when there are different groups of people surrounding the area....some was like lost souls looking for directions, while some gather in between the way waiting for their friends, and you have those looking up and low for the right belt for their luggage. We only found our luggage outside the luggage belt area, where there was a sign with the SQ Airlines logo on the floor. There was quite a handful of luggage that was located there, which obviously most of those taking the same flight as us were still stuck in immigration. Imagine the time taken from the moment we disembark from the plane and just to get out until our luggage was left outside and not at the belt.... This can be rather challenging, especially after coming a long "way" out from immigration Thought we are only required to transit to the arrival hall as a 1 time off thingy. Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient. We have to endure our thirst till our flight takes off. As a tourist, the airport gives the 1st impression for passengers and how they are organized. Hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements.

TEXT: Exhausting.. you need to have at least a year of airport work experience to just transit through this airport. It took nearly 2 hrs from landing to sitting down at our gate. So much is automated, and very few staff members to help, so when something goes wrong - like when the self bag-drop off machine stops working.. with one of our bags halfway through the conveyor, we were left for ages, not knowing what to do. So many more hurdles to jump such as filling in an MDAC, yes, we were asked to fill it in on-line at Siem Reap, but thought it couldn't possibly be for us as so many 'mandatory' boxes were irrelevant to us. However, at the airport, they insisted we filled it in with a bunch of false information, i.e. the address where we would be staying (had to put in an address that they provided.. which was the airport's address) a waste of time, as we felt we could miss our connecting flight. We also had to create our own baggage tags, then TWO separate baggage screenings - so unnecessary. There are so many options of queues without clear instructions, so many people, so much walking - it just seemed chaotic. It's not my favourite airport. If we weren't so tired.. we had been travelling all day, I would have said a pretty average airport.

TEXT: My recent experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) was unfortunately extremely disappointing. Firstly, the staff were generally unfriendly and appeared to have minimal understanding of English, which made basic communication difficult to impossible. More critically, there was a noticeable general incompetence across various functions. Staff seemed unable or unwilling to perform their duties, such as overseeing passengers and maintaining order in the queues. An additional major point of inefficiency was the self-service process: I was directed to the scanner by immigration staff, only for the scanner to then instruct me to return to the immigration counter, causing further unnecessary delays and frustration. I repeatedly observed an absolute lack of professional supervision, where people were simply allowed to cut in line or where queues dissolved into chaos without any staff intervention. This combination of poor (and by times even disrespectful) customer service, language barriers, and failure to enforce basic operational procedures led to unnecessary stress and delays. It's clear that KLIA urgently needs to invest in significantly better training for its personnel, focusing on customer service, language proficiency, and core job efficiency. If I could give 0 stars, I would!

TEXT: I recently traveled to Malaysia with my family, including young children, and was extremely disappointed by the poor management at the airport upon our arrival. After our plane landed, we had to wait for two full hours just to get through immigration. The lines were incredibly long, and there were no clear directions, very few staff members to assist, and an overall lack of organization in managing the arriving passengers. My children and elderly family members were forced to stand the entire time, which was both exhausting and unacceptable after a long flight. I expected better from a major international airport. There was no prioritization for families with children, no proper communication, and very little effort to speed up the process. It felt like the airport was completely unprepared to handle the volume of passengers arriving. My advice to the airport management: Please improve the arrival process by increasing staff at immigration counters, organizing separate queues for families, and providing clearer signage and communication. Travelers come to Malaysia expecting hospitality and efficiency unfortunately, this experience was neither welcoming nor efficient. I hope my feedback will be taken seriously to ensure a better experience for future visitors.

TEXT: The organization is good, in departure mode, although there are few travelers. However, it's dirty and somewhat rundown. The restrooms are okay. In arrival mode, it's indeed confusing where's the luggage??? And if you're arriving from a two-hour flight and have a jet lag, it's very complicated. Nothing or very little is written. TEXT: I don't know if T1 is better, but flew off from T2 and the system really needs more work and thinking through. Starting from the immigration gates, we were all directed to use the e-gates. There were Chinese tourists who were stuck, and they couldn't understand the error message that was in English. But there was not a single staff present? How can such gates be left unattended? All other tourists behind were left stranded. After the e-gates, our bags were scanned. So we emptied out all our water. In the departure hall we spotted water coolers so we refilled our bottles. As we were walking to the gate, there was suddenly another security screening?? And so we had to empty our bottles again?? Guess what, the water coolers at the boarding gate were not working. Passengers at T2 are on budget flights with no beverages. We needed the water. Also, the whole airport smelt of vomit and pee. I don't think KLIA is anywhere near calling themselves an internationally recognized airport. Not by a long shot. If someone from KLIA is reading this, please take this feedback seriously to improve your airport.

TEXT: It's still a great airport that meet the customers demand, but there are some run down facility and hardware, such as aged carpet with visible discoloration at the arrival hall, and some run down toilets with dim lamps. However the immigration section has been improved to cater the huge crowd of tourists. That's a good thing. Nevertheless, the custom checkpoint no longer provide the green zone for people with light luggages to walk thru. Everyone has to queue up to pass thru the custom checkpoint, where the officers will randomly pick any large luggage to scan for taxable items. So, be prepared for that. By the way, the departure hall do not have any water dispenser for you to refill your water bottle. You have to buy water with a sealed plastic bag (the bag is not free), in order to take it into the waiting hall. This is allowed by security check at the waiting hall. The new aerotrain ride between the satellite building and main building was good. Albeit it is a new train, there were a few events of disruption due to technical glitch (via news portals), so be prepared to take the buses again.

TEXT: We recently traveled from Malaysia to Cochin via KLIA with AirAsia, and unfortunately, the experience with the ground staff was very disappointing. We wanted to check in our baggage directly at the counter instead of using the kiosk, and when we asked the staff about it, their response was rude and unhelpful. They just told us to either use the kiosk or pay cash and try another counter, with no intention to assist further. At the V counter, a staff member initially told us to join the queue. But when we reached the front, the person issuing boarding passes and bag tags questioned how we got there and rudely told us to go back. Even when we explained that another AirAsia staff member had asked us to wait in line, she denied it outright, saying no one from their team would do that. There was a serious lack of coordination, professionalism, and courtesy from the ground staff. It left a very bad impression on us. AirAsia should really consider training their ground staff better, especially when handling international travelers who expect basic respect and guidance.

TEXT: KLIA1 Renovation: A Step Forward, But Wheres the Local Charm? Ive traveled through KLIA countless times over the years, and it has always impressed me with its cleanliness, smooth check-in process, and efficient security checks. The architecture, inspired by Malaysian, Islamic, and natural elements, remains a stunning highlight. But what truly made KLIA special was its balance of international and uniquely local offerings- something that now seems to be fading. With the recent KLIA1 renovation, I have to give credit where its duethe new bathrooms are a huge improvement! Well-designed, clean, and dry. But the retail and dining experience has taken a disappointing turn. Many local options have disappeared, replaced by foreign goods. And once again, alcohol and tobacco seem to dominate the retail spacewhy so much of it? I was shocked to find just one shelf of Malaysian food products in the entire terminal 1. Malaysia is a food paradisewhy isnt KLIA celebrating this? Instead, the vibrancy of local flavors is being replaced by the bland sameness of foreign caf chains, croissants, and cakes. More AUTHENTIC local options would be a delight!- especially for those leaving home and craving one last nasi lemak or kuey teow or teh tarik or curried roti? Once, travelers could enjoy authentic Malaysian dishes like kaya toast, prawn noodles, and teh tarik. Now, the F&B scene is overrun by global chains like Starbucks and Gloria Jeans. Surely, KLIA can do better by making space for homegrown eateries that showcase Malaysias rich culinary diversity? To add to the frustration, the monorail is still out of service (Ive lost count how long Ive waited), forcing travelers to rely on slow and inefficient shuttle buses. And when I asked an Ask Me For Help staff member for food recommendations, she barely looked up from her phone. Customer service should be better than this! KLIA, lets do better! Support local businesses and bring back the authentic Malaysian experience to travellers.
processed_text: klia1 renovation step forward wheres local charm ive travel countless time year always impress cleanliness smooth checkin process efficient security check architecture inspire malaysian islamic natural element remain stunning highlight truly make special balance international uniquely local offering something seem fade recent klia1 renovation give credit duethe new bathroom huge improvement welldesigned clean dry retail din experience take disappointing turn many local option disappear replace foreign good alcohol tobacco seem dominate retail spacewhy much shock find one shelf malaysian food product entire terminal 1 malaysia food paradisewhy isnt celebrate instead vibrancy local flavor replace bland sameness foreign caf chain croissant cake authentic local option would delight especially leave home crave one last nasi lemak kuey teow teh tarik curry roti traveler could enjoy authentic malaysian dish like kaya toast prawn noodle teh tarik fb scene overrun global chain like starbucks gloria jean surely good make space homegrown eatery showcase malaysias rich culinary diversity add frustration monorail still service ive lose count long ive wait force traveler rely slow inefficient shuttle bus ask ask help staff member food recommendation barely look phone customer service good let good support local business bring back authentic malaysian experience traveller

TEXT: The airport is modern, spacious, and generally well-run. However, there were a few moments of confusion worth mentioning. Upon arrival, the immigration process was not clearly marked. Passengers with Malaysian passports go through a different gate than those with foreign passports, but the signage didnt make that obvious. Additionally, all international visitors must fill out a digital arrival form about their stay. There were enough computers available to do this at the airport, but the form isnt very intuitive, and it requires knowing the exact address of your accommodation. It could definitely be made more user-friendly. The departure experience was quick, smooth, and without queues. However, just before boarding the plane, there was a second bag check, and surprisingly, you couldnt bring any drinks on board not even those in your own bottles or purchased in the terminal. Only drinks sealed in security bags by the shop were allowed, and not all stores offer this option. Unfortunately, no one informed us of this at the time of purchase, which was frustrating and once again showed a lack of clear communication.
processed_text: airport modern spacious generally wellrun however moment confusion worth mention upon arrival immigration process clearly marked passenger malaysian passport go different gate foreign passport signage didnt make obvious additionally international visitor must fill digital arrival form stay enough computer available airport form isnt intuitive require know exact address accommodation could definitely make userfriendly departure experience quick smooth without queue however board plane second bag check surprisingly couldnt bring drink board even bottle purchase terminal drink seal security bag shop allow store offer option unfortunately one inform u time purchase frustrate show lack clear communication

TEXT: This airport is quite impressive, but the distance to the next gate is really far, and I ended up pretty tired from walking. The international departure lounge is really small, disorganized, and lacks proper management. The toilet maintenance is poor, and the cleanliness is not well-kept. Also, there are very few seats in the corridor before entering the waiting area, so a lot of people have to sit on the floor, almost like a refugee camp. There are very few water dispensers and phone charging stations, and people have to wait in line just to charge their phones. The immigration staff is unfriendly and treats passengers rudely. Overall, it was a pretty disappointing experience at this airport.

TEXT: I don't know if it's under the responsibility of AirAsia or the airport management, but I traveled in a lot of countries (poor or not), and I never seen such poor airport management. 1. TEXT: My second trip through Kuala Lumpur International Airport was unfortunately just as frustrating as the first. The customer service here is a huge problem. I asked multiple staff members for help with basic info, and every single one just shrugged, said "I don't know" and acted like it wasn't their job. There was zero effort to even try and find out. It's truly baffling. Then there's the internal airport bus with no proper monitoring. We had our 5-month-old with us and we literally had to stand for a 5-minute ride between gates. The bus wasn't even packed but everyone was too busy hogging their spot to offer one up to someone struggling with a baby. The fear of losing balance and dropping our infant was terrifying. People just sat there watching us, completely uncaring. To top it off, we saw a couple of electric buggies nearby, clearly for passenger assistance, but there was no one to drive them! We asked four different staff if they could help us get one, and each time, we got the same clueless "I don't know" response. For an international airport, the lack of basic help and common courtesy is really poor. Traveling with a baby is already tough enough, and KLIA just made it worse. I'll definitely be trying to avoid this airport next time.

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is huge, so be prepared for long walks between terminals and sometimes even bus rides to reach your connecting gate. If you have a connecting flight, plan extra time and check in advance which terminal you're flying from KLIA1 and KLIA2 are far apart. Make sure to exchange currency in advance if you need to buy anything; US dollars might work at some counters, but it's better to have Malaysian Ringgit. The waiting areas are basic, mostly just chairs no proper couches if youre trying to relax during a layover. Overall, the airport is well-organized, but you need to be alert and prepared especially for tight connections.

TEXT: I was assaulted by a female airport customer experience officer who attempted to physically restrain me without justification. When I demanded to file a police report, I was told I would have to go to Terminal 2something my Australian emergency passport did not permit. Despite my repeated requests, the airport police refused to take my report and instead escorted me to the immigration department. There, I was met by an aggressive and unprofessional immigration officer named Kamarudin. When I asked for his full name in writing, he refused and rudely pointed to his name badge, telling me to take a photo with my phone. The moment I did, he became enraged and began intimidating meeven going so far as to take photos of me and my passport on his personal phone. This was a blatant violation of privacy and professional conduct. **Malaysias airport authorities and immigration officers behaved in a disgusting, abusive, and unaccountable manner. Travelers beware: AVOID MALAYSIA at all costs!**

TEXT: It might be more appropriate to call it Kuala Lumpur Airport rather than 'International.' While the airport is generally clean and well-lit, the transit area is underwhelming. Wi-Fi connectivity is slow, and there are limited food and retail options. A significant upgrade or expansion is needed if the airport aims to keep up with other regional hubs. Additionally, the transport pick-up experience at Terminal 2 was a nightmare. The poorly designed two-lane pick-up area created severe congestion, and we ended up waiting over an hour just to be picked up. It's unclear who was responsible for this layout, but it clearly needs a serious rethink

TEXT: My recent experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) was nothing short of frustrating. The immigration officers are rude and disrespectful, making an already stressful experience far worse. To be honest, it felt like the staff were completely uninterested in their job, and some even seemed to resent being there. In Malaysia, government jobs, including those at airports prioritize ethnic Malays over Indian and Chinese Malays. As a result, some government positions, such as immigration officers or airport staff, may be filled based on ethnicity rather than merit or qualifications. Due to this, individuals in these roles might lack the necessary qualifications or passion for the job, which can sometimes be reflected in their job performance and attitude. What really stood out was the slogan displayed upon arrival: We hope youve enjoyed our Malaysian Hospitality. Frankly, this felt more like an empty promise than a reflection of the experience I had. A service should speak for itself, but in this case, it was clear that overcompensating with slogans only highlights the gap between what is advertised and what is actually delivered. Given this experience, I will never fly with Malaysian Airlines or visit Malaysia again and I certainly won't be encouraging my friends or family to visit. Avoid countries that do not respect and appreciate tourist coming to help their economy!

TEXT: It might be more appropriate to call it Kuala Lumpur Airport rather than 'International.' While the airport is generally clean and well-lit, the transit area is underwhelming. Wi-Fi connectivity is slow, and there are limited food and retail options. A significant upgrade or expansion is needed if the airport aims to keep up with other regional hubs. Additionally, the transport pick-up experience at Terminal 2 was a nightmare. The poorly designed two-lane pick-up area created severe congestion, and we ended up waiting over an hour just to be picked up. It's unclear who was responsible for this layout, but it clearly needs a serious rethink

TEXT: I love Malaysia and have visited many times, but KLIA is honestly one of the worst airport experiences Ive ever had. We arrived as a family with kids (8 months, 3, 7, and 9 years old). The family/elderly lane was a joke the officer let some families with older kids go through, but told us only our 1 years baby can enter with his mother and the rest should go another Lane. When I asked why, he completely ignored me. It felt discriminatory and unprofessional. Immigration was a nightmare: 75 minutes in line just for slow biometric checks, while our luggage was left unattended off the belt. On the return back home, an immigration officer told us our family was too big and refused to process all six passports, forcing us to split up. I have never seen such behavior in any international airport. Most Immigration officers were too rude. To make things worse: Batik Air check-in staff were rude and lied about baggage weight, and duty-free prices were ridiculously overpriced (almost 3x more than outside). All of this happened in one single trip. For a country that wants to be a top tourist destination, KLIA is a serious embarrassment.

TEXT: Unfortunately, my experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport was disappointing. Here are a few points that struck me negatively: 1. Strict baggage control, but not consistent: My hand luggage was accurately weighed, and even though it was only slightly over 6kg, I was told to pay extra. At the same time, the Malaysian woman in front of me, weighing almost 8 kg, was allowed to walk away - that felt unfair. 2. Poor Signage: Some gates had no numbers, which was extremely confusing. It was difficult to find the right path. 3. Lack of seating: There were no seats at the gate, which made the wait unnecessarily tiring. 4. Inadequate Toilets: The women's restrooms were a mess - I waited in line for over 30 minutes and when it was finally my turn, they were dirty. The men apparently had enough toilets as there were no queues. Unfortunately, the airport was the worst I've ever been to.

TEXT: Horrible, just horrible!! The worst experience in my life, and I've been to many airports. Automation of everything is disgusting! TEXT: I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines. While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, I was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight. Although the airport is large and packed with many shops and eateries, there are a few areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving passengers. - These include having clearer directional signs/ large screen and more readily available information. Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member..standing at the side, to go to Cxx for a transfer to the arrival hall. Rather than having a staff member saying out to those passengers embarking, there might be a chance people will miss that important message. - Wouldn't it be better to put up clear large signage at both sides of the walkway while we disembarked? - Would also suggest considering adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay. The signage for this bus transfer was also unclear, and it took us a while to find the area just to queue for a feeder bus. Since this airport is named as an international airport, wouldnt it be better to have a basic international standard too? The situation worsened upon arrival at the arrival hall. The area was extremely crowded, and people are in queue of 2 -3 lines in a row....resulting in a queue of over an hour just to clear immigration. Very disorganized and messy, no one was there to direct the human traffic, which leads to all these mess. After clearing immigration, locating the correct baggage belt was challenging. The area was crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts where you needed to walk near the belt to check on the medium-sized monitor screen showing which flight these belts are meant for. The screen flashed so fast with so many people trying to catch a glimpse of the information, which was rather frustrating, especially when there are different groups of people surrounding the area....some was like lost souls looking for directions, while some gather in between the way waiting for their friends, and you have those looking up and low for the right belt for their luggage. Literally, many passengers were visibly struggling to find their luggage, moving up and down, left and right. We only found our luggage outside the luggage belt area, where there was a sign with the SQ Airlines logo on the floor. There was quite a handful of luggage that was located there, which obviously most of those taking the same flight as us were still stuck in immigration. Imagine the time taken from the moment we disembark from the plane and just to get out until our luggage was left outside and not at the belt.... Navigating the airport area to find a Grab was also confusing due to the signage, much of which was in Malay. This can be rather challenging, especially after coming a long "way" out from immigration We thought maybe this is common for arrival passengers to encounter. Who knows, we must go through the same things going back. On our return flight, we were once again required to take a short bus to the departure hall. Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient. We have to endure our thirst till our flight takes off. As a tourist, the airport gives the 1st impression for passengers and how they are organized. This wasn't the kind of experience I was expecting from KLIA. Hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements.

TEXT: I recently traveled through KLIA and was quite disappointed with the overall experience. The ground staff were uncooperative and extremely slow it took me 45 minutes just to drop my luggage, which is unacceptable for a major international airport. There was a clear lack of urgency and coordination among the staff, which caused unnecessary delays and frustration. The immigration process was no better. Officers were more engaged in chatting among themselves than assisting travelers. When it came to the facial recognition scan, there was no clear instruction on when to stop looking into the camera, leading to confusion and further hold-ups. Such negligence and poor communication from immigration staff are not what you'd expect from a facility that aims to be a gateway to the country. Overall, KLIA seriously needs to step up its service standards. Staff training, efficiency, and customer interaction must be improved if the airport wants to compete with other major international hubs. I hope the management takes these issues seriously and implements changes soon.

TEXT: This airport made me never want to come back to Malaysia. Who designed this place?! First, the walk from the plane to immigration and baggage claim was unbelievably long. Ive traveled through many large airports, but Ive never had to walk this much just to reach my luggage. I could overlook that but what came next was even worse. After collecting our bags and passing immigration, we were forced to walk through a mall to get to the exit. Yes, a literal mall where every airport in the world you'd be checking your transportation to finally leave. After a long flight, the last thing anyone wants is to be dragged through a maze of stores just to leave the airport. It felt like a cash grab, not a travel hub. We finally made it out and were relieved to see Grab was available (were used to it from Thailand). But when we booked a ride, the wait time was 35 minutes! There was a huge, overcrowded Grab waiting area with screens showing incoming car plates, clearly, demand was way beyond what the airport could handle. Tired and frustrated, we gave up on Grab, hoping to catch a bus instead. But we werent allowed to buy tickets until exactly 12 PM, which was also the listed departure time, because it's too late now to buy tickets (15 minutes ahead). We were told the bus would leave even after 12. The whole thing felt disorganized and unclear and the wait time seemed same as the Grab and the destination station is not even close to the hotel. In the end, we paid over double the Grab fare to take a regular taxi, just to get the hell out of there. This airport is a logistical mess and a terrible first impression of Malaysia.

TEXT: Welcome to KLIA2 (Terminal 2), one of the 2 terminal of KL International Airport - the proud home of AirAsia and every traveler who thought budget travel just meant a cheap ticket, not a 1.2km hike from immigration to Gate J22. Built more like a shopping mall that occasionally remembers its an airport, KLIA2 offers you the chance to buy bubble tea, sushi, and Crocs all before even hitting security. Need retail therapy at 3 a.m.? Youre in luck. Need a quiet seat with a charging port? Hah, good luck. Stat corner: Opened in 2014 to replace the low-cost LCCT terminal, KLIA2 is the largest purpose-built terminal for low-cost carriers in the world. Its also a maze where time and boarding calls are mere suggestions. Still, with AirAsias mantra of Now Everybody Can Fly, this terminal proves it , whether youre a backpacker, a broke student, or someone who accidentally booked the wrong airport entirely. Pro tip: ARRIVE EARLY, wear comfy shoes, and emotionally prepare for a shopping mall with a runway.

TEXT: I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines. While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, I was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight. Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member, who was shouting, to proceed to Cxx for a transfer to the arrival hall. Was thinking that perhaps our flight was scheduled to park in a further lot due to multiple flights arriving around the same time. Personally, I wasnt expecting to go through the hassle of having to transit from the plane to the arrival hall, taking into consideration that this was a direct flight. Anyway, still went with the flow and follow those in front since we are told to.... This information could easily be missed if people are talking or focused on finding the nearest toilet. Although the airport was large and packed with lots of shops and eateries, there are areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving/departure passengers. Would suggest the following improvements: * Rather than having a staff member shouting/giving instructions, can consider placing clear, large signage on both sides of the walkway as passengers disembark. * Provide more readily available information upon flight arrival / departure. * Consider adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay. Clear directional signs and information would make a big difference for first-time visitors like myself and would save a lot of time especially when there are so many incoming/outgoing flights day to day..... The signage for the bus transfer was unclear, and it took approximately 4-5 minutes to find the waiting point to queue for the feeder bus to the arrival hall. Upon arriving at the arrival hall, it was another 2-minute walk to reach immigration. The area was extremely crowded, with queues of 2-3 lines in a row, resulting in an hour-long wait to clear immigration. The process was very disorganized and messy, with no one managing the human traffic, possibly due to a shortage of manpower. Although the officers were friendly and efficient in clearing the queue, it would be beneficial to have crowd control/security to guide and manage the flow of passengers. Locating the correct baggage belt after clearing immigration was another challenge. The area was crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts, requiring passengers to walk near the belt to check the monitor screen. This was frustrating, especially with different groups of people surrounding the area, some looking for directions, some waiting for friends, and others searching for the right belt. We eventually found our luggage placed not far away from the luggage belt area near the exit, with a sign displaying the SQ Airlines logo on the floor. Many unclaimed bags from our flight were present, as most passengers were still stuck in immigration. The entire process, from disembarking the plane to retrieving our luggage outside the baggage claim area, was challenging. I thought we were only required to transit to the arrival hall as a one-time occurrence. However, on our return flight, we were once again required to take a short bus to the departure hall. Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient. As a tourist, the airport gives the first impression for passengers, and its organization is crucial. I hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements

TEXT: One of the worst airport experiences Ive ever had. While the airport is spacious, the design is extremely confusing. Each level has two separate sides, and if you accidentally end up on the wrong one, you have to go back up and re-enter from another point theres no direct way to cross over. The terminals are connected by trains, but shockingly, youre charged 2 MYR per person just to use them! Shuttle buses are available, but only from specific areas that take at least 30 minutes of walking to reach, with no clear guidance. There are no proper information desks, and youre left to ask random staff who often give vague or conflicting directions. To make matters worse, baggage trolley staff were communicating using loud whistles it was chaotic and very unpleasant. The AirAsia terminal (2) was particularly bad and felt extremely disorganized. This experience alone is enough to make me reconsider visiting Malaysia again just to avoid going through this airport.

TEXT: I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines. While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, I was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight. Although the airport is large and packed with many shops and eateries, there are a few areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving passengers. These include having clearer directional signs/ large screen and more readily available information. Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member to go to C15 for a transfer to the arrival hall. Rather having a staff to shout ,wouldn't it be better to put up clear large signage at both side of the walk way while we disembark? The signage for this bus transfer was also unclear, and it took us a while to find the area just to queue for a feeder bus. Would also suggest considering adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay. Since this airport is named as an international airport, wouldnt it be better to have basic international standard too? Situation worsened upon arrival at the arrival hall. The area was extremely crowded,people are in queue of 2 -3 lines in a row....resulting in a queue of over an hour just to clear immigration. Very disorganized and messy, no one was there to direct the human traffic which leads to all these mess. After clearing immigration, locating the correct baggage belt was challenging. The area was crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts where you needed to walk near the belt to check on the medium-sized monitor screen showing which flight these belts are meant for. The screen flashed so fast with so many people trying to catch a glimpse of the information, which was rather frustrating, especially when yiu have different groups of people surrounding the area....some was waiting for their friends while some was was looking for the right belt for their luggage. Literally, many passengers were visibly struggling to find their luggage, moving up and down, left and right. We only found our luggage outside the luggage belt area, where there was a sign with the Singapore Airlines logo on the floor. Quite a handful of luggage was located there, which obviously most of those taking the same flight were still stuck in immigration. Imagine the time taken from the moment we disembark from the plane and just to get out until our luggage was left outside and not at the belt. Navigating the airport area to find a Grab was also confusing due to the signage much of which was in Malay. This can be rather challenging, especially after a series of such "events" we went through. We thought maybe this is common for arrival passengers to encounter, who knows we must go through the same things going back. On our return flight, we were once again required to take a short bus to the departure hall. Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient.We have to endure our thirst till our flight take off. As a tourist, I dont enjoy it if I have to go through so much hassle. This was one of a kind of experience i wasn't expecting from KLIA... Hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements.

TEXT: The organization is good, in departure mode, although there are few travelers. On the other hand, it's dirty and somewhat rundown. TEXT: The airport looks very fancy and all - at least Terminal 1. It is very unorganized though. We arrived extremely late from our first flight (thank you batik air) and only had 15-20min items to get our connecting flight. Normally airports would provide a shuttle services, picking you from a gate to bring you to your connecting flight in time. This was not the case here, we were only told the gate number of our connecting flight, which after running to for 10min, turned out to be the wrong gate. So instead we had to take the bus to another terminal, which obviously did not give us enough time to catch our flight, so we were stuck in KL for 1 night. Additionally it is ridiculous, that there is no smoking area in the entirety of terminal 1. So if you are stuck here for a while you have to go all the way to terminal 2, into one of the most disgusting smoking rooms Ive witnessed in my life (no ventilation at all, might as well just walk in and breath twice and youve already passively smoked a carton of cigarettes). Really disappointing for such a modern (only t1) and large airport.

TEXT: Arriving: Immigration for arrivals took too long! The officers works so slowly and the poor internet connection in this area is not helping either. It took us long enough to complete immigration to the point that our bags were no longer in the conveyor belt/shown on screen. Pick up location of ride hailing (Grab) was easy at Level 1. Departure: Check in counters are spread out making it not too crowded/congested. Immigration for departure is quicker and easier. However, there's a security screening for customs departure that was separated with at-gate security check. I would say this is very inefficient as you need to check your bags twice and once you have cleared security you practically cannot go out to the retail area. In addition, the post-security gate is a nightmare with neither water stations nor proper toilet! There seems to be no signs of priority boarding based on group but rather by seats (not sure if this is an MH or KLIA problem). Retail space is decent with great tax-free goods options and decent restaurant selections. One thing to appreciate: the toilets (in retail & public) areas are clean and equipped with jet showers.

TEXT: Exhausting.. you need to have atleast a year of airport work experience to just transit through this airport. It took nearly 2 hrs from landing to sitting down at our gate. So many options of queues without clear instructions, so many people, so much walking - just seems chaotic. Not my favourite airport.

TEXT: Arrived at Kuala Lumpur in the late afternoon, and the queue at immigration was very long. We got in and waited about 15 minutes, when we left there were 2-3 times as many people, so they must have waited for over 30 minutes. There are not many officers. But the thing that annoyed the most, was the lack of transparency regarding the newly introduced MDAC that every foreigner needs to fill in. About 20% of the people in the queue wait for a long time, and then when coming to the immigration officer they did not fill in the MDAC and the foreigner is redirected to the back again to fill it in. It is a waste of time for people waiting, the immigration officers and for the people who did not fill it in. It is very simple, put some signage to be clear at the start of the queue. "Did you fill in your MDAC?". If not, fill it in first. I literally filled it in in 2 minutes while I was in the long queue. Sure, everyone needs to do their own research. But from a big airport like Kuala Lumpur, this is terrible organization and messes with people who have connecting flights.
