TEXT: I was assaulted by a female airport customer experience officer who attempted to physically restrain me without justification. When I demanded to file a police report, I was told I would have to go to Terminal 2something my Australian emergency passport did not permit. Despite my repeated requests, the airport police refused to take my report and instead escorted me to the immigration department. There, I was met by an aggressive and unprofessional immigration officer named Kamarudin. When I asked for his full name in writing, he refused and rudely pointed to his name badge, telling me to take a photo with my phone. The moment I did, he became enraged and began intimidating meeven going so far as to take photos of me and my passport on his personal phone. This was a blatant violation of privacy and professional conduct. **Malaysias airport authorities and immigration officers behaved in a disgusting, abusive, and unaccountable manner. Travelers beware: AVOID MALAYSIA at all costs!** **Legal Analysis** This conduct raises multiple violations under Malaysian law: 1. **Assault and Criminal Force (Penal Code Sections 350-352)** The staff member's actions in grabbing my arms and physically restraining me without consent constitutes criminal force under Section 350. Case precedent (PP v. Mohd Anuar bin Abdullah [1994] 2 MLJ 261) confirms that any intentional use of force without lawful justification meets this threshold. 2. **Wrongful Confinement (Penal Code Section 340)** The unlawful restriction of my movement within the clinic treatment room amounts to wrongful confinement. Malaysian jurisprudence establishes that detention without legal authority is punishable, particularly where no legitimate lien exists over the person. 3. **Official Misconduct** The behavior of Immigration Officer Kamarudin in: - Failing to properly address a criminal complaint - Intimidating a complainant - Improper use of personal devices to photograph sensitive documents May constitute offenses under Malaysia's official misconduct provisions. UPDATE: Malaysian Airport Management have promised a full investigation of this matter however no official response as of yet.

TEXT: Poor signage means that navigating around the airport is difficult. The layout is also poorly designed because the security is at each gate, meaning that you're not allowed to take any water onto your flight. You also don't know roughly how long it will take to get from the main terminal to the gate At the gate you're asked to provide a printed boarding card even if you have an online booking. TEXT: What happened to KLIA? I loved this airport. It was clean, friendly, quick and easy to get through. But the past few times it was horrible: long lines, unfriendly and unhelpful staff, angry travelers, expensive food (yes, more expensive) and more. Toilets are overal dirty too. Travelers are also unfriendly and loud. Not KLIAs fault, but nobody seems to care. Cellphones everywhere playing all kind of videos, loud phone calls, and playing music that's just horrible. The rain forest thing seems a joke to me. Nice idea, but its advertised as if its huge. It's not, its small. Nice view through a window inside it, because it was closed and I have no idea if its normally open to enter. When I went through security it felt to easy, and it was. It seems gates have a second security point. No clear lines, no communication, and everyone is pushing and pulling to get through. Staff dont seem to care. I almost missed my flight because there were 4 lines for 1 gate and nobody knew who could go through. Add some clear lines or something. Two positive things: arriving is pretty simple and quick. And when leaving I know I will be in a plane at some point.

TEXT: One of the worst airport experiences Ive ever had. While the airport is spacious, the design is extremely confusing. Each level has two separate sides, and if you accidentally end up on the wrong one, you have to go back up and re-enter from another point theres no direct way to cross over. The terminals are connected by trains, but shockingly, youre charged 2 MYR per person just to use them! Shuttle buses are available, but only from specific areas that take at least 30 minutes of walking to reach, with no clear guidance. There are no proper information desks, and youre left to ask random staff who often give vague or conflicting directions. To make matters worse, baggage trolley staff were communicating using loud whistles it was chaotic and very unpleasant. The AirAsia terminal (2) was particularly bad and felt extremely disorganized. This experience alone is enough to make me reconsider visiting Malaysia again just to avoid going through this airport.

TEXT: We flew with Batik Air and had to go to Gate G8. After check-in, you go through passport control for international flights. TEXT: Absolutely horrible check in process at Malaysia airport. I arrived at the aiport at 6 AM, 3 hours before my 9 AM flight, only to see a line of 500 people in front of me everyone checking in for Malaysia airlines flights at different times. Some people checking in for 11 AM flight and getting in the line. I had already done web check in, I had printed luggage tags and boarding pass, I just wanted to drop off my check in bag and go to my terminal for breakfast. But the whole process was organised so horribly that I was in the line for 1 hour only to check in my bag. Then another hour to reach my terminal and then 45 mins in line for boarding. I didnt get to have any breakfast or relax before my flight. Flight was delayed by 30+ mins on tarmac. Shame on Malaysia airlines and Malaysia airport for such terrible management. Next time I am going to buy Batik Air tickets.

TEXT: This airport made me never want to come back to Malaysia. Who designed this place?! First, the walk from the plane to immigration and baggage claim was unbelievably long. Ive traveled through many large airports, but Ive never had to walk this much just to reach my luggage. I could overlook that but what came next was even worse. After collecting our bags and passing immigration, we were forced to walk through (GET THIS!) A MALL to get to the exit. Yes, a literal mall where every airport in the world you'd be checking your transportation to finally leave. After a long flight, the last thing anyone wants is to be dragged through a maze of stores just to leave the airport. It felt like a cash grab, not a travel hub. We finally made it out and were relieved to see Grab was available (were used to it from Thailand). But when we booked a ride, the wait time was 35 minutes! There was a huge, overcrowded Grab waiting area with screens showing incoming car plates, clearly, demand was way beyond what the airport could handle. Tired and frustrated, we gave up on Grab, hoping to catch a bus instead. But we werent allowed to buy tickets until exactly 12 AM, which was also the listed departure time of the bus, "because it's too late now to buy tickets" (15 minutes ahead). We were told the bus would leave even after 12. The whole thing felt disorganized and unclear and the wait time seemed same as the Grab and the destination station is not even close to the hotel. In the end, we paid almost triple the Grab fare to take a regular taxi, just to get the hell out of there. And also, the airport wifi is not available once you finish immigration! I had such a hard time to book the Grab taxi and check information and chat with my airbnb host because there was no wifi after immigration, in any airport that's when wifi is needed!! But here there's a freakin' mall between the airport and the exits!!! I've never had this much hastle and wasted time to manage to exit an airport, oh yeah, and the airport is so far away from the city it took us 90 minutes to reach the hotel (with zero traffic after midnight) knowing this, the designers still decided to add a mall to make your trip even slower! This airport is a logistical mess and a terrible first impression of Malaysia. I've never thought an airport would affect my will to visit a country but here we are.

TEXT: A more than bad experience... I arrived at the airport at 7:00 AM, and went directly to wrap my large bag. There were only two people in front of me, but the wrapping took longer than expected. When I got to the baggage check-in counter, I found the queue very long, and my turn didn't come until 8:15 AM!!! The flight gate opened... When I finished, I didn't know where to go to find the gate, so I asked one of the employees, and her response was very... When she left, she started mocking me in front of the shop owners, as she imitated the way I spoke in front of them. I didn't have time to stop her because this is a disrespectful way to treat tourists and guests in general... Anyway, when I finally got to the bus stop, I found another queue, and we went to the bus, thank God... But the surprise was that there was another inspection before boarding the plane!!!! This caused the backlog and queues again!!!! One of the worst airport experiences in my life. Unprofessional and slow employees, poor airport management and organization. Finally, the plane didn't take off after this chaos until half an hour after the official takeoff time, and I was forced to stand during these three hours because of the boring and tiring queues. A bad experience by all standards.

TEXT: My recent experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport was shockingly poor and has completely soured my view of Malaysia. Arriving late at night, I was met with an appalling three-hour wait in the immigration queue. With only two counters open, the already tired and frustrated passengers were subjected to rude and unprofessional behavior from the immigration officers. One officer, who identified himself as Nizam, was particularly aggressive, yelling at passengers and making demeaning comments about their attempts to use the biometric scanners. His dismissive attitude and condescending tone were echoed by other staff members, creating a hostile and uncomfortable atmosphere for everyone, including families with young children. The situation worsened when, due to the extensive delay, our luggage was removed from the baggage carousel. This added further stress and inconvenience to an already exhausting experience. It felt as though the immigration staff treated their positions as some sort of celebrity status, rather than a service role. The impact of this disastrous airport experience rippled through my entire trip. I had to cancel some planned tourist attractions due to the excessive wait times I encountered elsewhere, including another two-hour queue. My children were exhausted, and our holiday was ultimately ruined. As if the airport ordeal wasn't enough, our tourist vehicle was later stopped by police for a seemingly pointless immigration check, resulting in another hour-long delay. This unnecessary display of authority felt like a final insult. It's ironic that Malaysia's economy relies heavily on tourism, yet visitors are treated with such disrespect. This entire experience was so negative that I will never visit Malaysia again. It's truly a shame, as I had hoped for a much more positive experience.

TEXT: Chaotic. We flew British Airways business class and it wasn't clear that we needed to go to gate G1, downstairs and take a bus to C gates, where Golden Lounge is. We walked around the main terminal being sent in random directions before being told the right information. At check in, we should have been told go to Gate G1 and take a bus. The Golden Lounge was very large. The bar is right near the entrance, so sit near there if you want to have a drink or two. Obviously the serving of alcohol is controlled here. I ordered two sparkling wines; one for my partner too but I was only served one. I had to ask for the second one and I felt judged for doing so. The glasses were small and the wine wasn't good. There was lots of hot food choices; far more than any other business lounge I have been too. Sandwiches, pasta and noodles made to order. Lots of other self-serve foods too. Don't try to take any drinks from the lounge, as you aren't allowed to take any onboard from this airport.

TEXT: I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines. While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, I was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight. Although the airport is large and packed with many shops and eateries, there are a few areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving passengers. These include having clearer directional signs/ large screen and more readily available information. Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member to go to C15 for a transfer to the arrival hall. Rather having a staff to shout ,wouldn't it be better to put up clear signage at both side of the walk way while we disembark? The signage for this bus transfer was unclear, and it took us a while to find the area just to queue for a feeder bus. Would also suggest considering adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay. Since this airport is named as an international airport, wouldnt it be better to have basic international standard too? Situation worsened upon arrival at the arrival hall. The area was extremely crowded,people are in queue of 2 -3 lines in a row....resulting in a queue of over an hour just to clear immigration. Very disorganized and messy, no one was there to direct the human traffic which leads to all these mess. After clearing immigration, locating the correct baggage belt was challenging. The area was crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts where you needed to walk near the belt to check on the medium-sized monitor screen showing which flight these belts are meant for. The screen flashed so fast with so many people trying to catch a glimpse of the information, which was rather frustrating, especially when yiu have different groups of people surrounding the area....some was waiting for their friends while some was was looking for the right belt for their luggage. Literally, many passengers were visibly struggling to find their luggage, moving up and down, left and right. We only found our luggage outside the luggage belt area, where there was a sign with the Singapore Airlines logo on the floor. Quite a handful of luggage was located there, which obviously most of those taking the same flight were still stuck in immigration. Imagine the time taken from the moment we disembark from the plane and just to get out until our luggage was left outside and not at the belt. Navigating the airport area to find a Grab was also confusing due to the signage much of which was in Malay. This can be rather challenging, especially after a series of such "events" we went through. We thought maybe this is common for arrival passengers to encounter, who knows we must go through the same things going back. On our return flight, we were once again required to take a short bus to the departure hall. Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient.We have to endure our thirst till our flight take off. As a tourist, I dont enjoy it if I have to go through so much hassle. This was one of a kind of experience i wasn't expecting from KLIA... Hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements.

TEXT: My recent experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) was unfortunately extremely disappointing. Firstly, the staff were generally unfriendly and appeared to have minimal understanding of English, which made basic communication difficult to impossible. More critically, there was a noticeable general incompetence across various functions. Staff seemed unable or unwilling to perform their duties, such as overseeing passengers and maintaining order in the queues. In this context, I repeatedly observed an absolute lack of professional supervision, where people were simply allowed to cut in line or where queues dissolved into chaos without any staff intervention. An additional major point of inefficiency was the self-service process: I was directed to the scanner by immigration staff, only for the scanner to then instruct me to return to the immigration counter, causing further unnecessary delays and frustration. Furthermore, the signage (wayfinding) was poor, often unclear, and lacked sufficient repetition throughout the terminal, making navigation difficult. To top it all off, there was also a lack of seating at the airport itself, and the seats that were available were often taken up by a single person lying down across three seats, leaving people who wanted to sit with nowhere to go. This combination of poor (and by times even disrespectful) customer service, language barriers, failure to enforce basic operational procedures and the lack of seating led to unnecessary stress and delays. It's clear that KLIA urgently needs to invest in significantly better training for its personnel, focusing on customer service, language proficiency, and core job efficiency. If I could give 0 stars, I would!

TEXT: My second trip through Kuala Lumpur International Airport was unfortunately just as frustrating as the first. The customer service here is a huge problem. I asked multiple staff members for help with basic info, and every single one just shrugged, said "I don't know" and acted like it wasn't their job. There was zero effort to even try and find out. It's truly baffling. Then there's the internal airport bus with no proper monitoring. We had our 5-month-old with us and we literally had to stand for a 5-minute ride between gates. The bus wasn't even packed but everyone was too busy hogging their spot to offer one up to someone struggling with a baby. The fear of losing balance and dropping our infant was terrifying. People just sat there watching us, completely uncaring. To top it off, we saw a couple of electric buggies nearby, clearly for passenger assistance, but there was no one to drive them! We asked four different staff if they could help us get one, and each time, we got the same clueless "I don't know" response. For an international airport, the lack of basic help and common courtesy is really poor. Traveling with a baby is already tough enough, and KLIA just made it worse. I'll definitely be trying to avoid this airport next time.

TEXT: This airport made me never want to come back to Malaysia. Who designed this place?! First, the walk from the plane to immigration and baggage claim was unbelievably long. Ive traveled through many large airports, but Ive never had to walk this much just to reach my luggage. I could overlook that but what came next was even worse. After collecting our bags and passing immigration, we were forced to walk through a mall to get to the exit. Yes, a literal mall where every airport in the world you'd be checking your transportation to finally leave. After a long flight, the last thing anyone wants is to be dragged through a maze of stores just to leave the airport. It felt like a cash grab, not a travel hub. We finally made it out and were relieved to see Grab was available (were used to it from Thailand). But when we booked a ride, the wait time was 35 minutes! There was a huge, overcrowded Grab waiting area with screens showing incoming car plates, clearly, demand was way beyond what the airport could handle. Tired and frustrated, we gave up on Grab, hoping to catch a bus instead. But we werent allowed to buy tickets until exactly 12 PM, which was also the listed departure time, because it's too late now to buy tickets (15 minutes ahead). We were told the bus would leave even after 12. The whole thing felt disorganized and unclear and the wait time seemed same as the Grab and the destination station is not even close to the hotel. In the end, we paid over double the Grab fare to take a regular taxi, just to get the hell out of there. This airport is a logistical mess and a terrible first impression of Malaysia.

TEXT: I visited Malaysia recently to attend a concert. I queued at immigration for almost two hours. When it was my turn, the officer did not smile or greet me back, despite my polite greeting. She only said Ticket? without explaining further. I showed my concert ticket, but she gave no response and told me to go back and queue again. I explained that I had already waited for over an hour, but she insisted without reason. Her tone and facial expressions were unfriendly, making my first impression of Malaysia very disappointing. Eventually, I showed all my documents and was allowed to pass. However, her attitude left a negative memory of the trip. I hope the management can provide proper training to ensure visitors are treated with courtesy.

TEXT: Ive traveled through KLIA countless times over the years, and it has always stood out for its cleanliness, smooth check-in process, and efficient security checks. The architecture, inspired by Malaysian, Islamic, and natural elements, is a beautiful highlight. But what truly made KLIA special was its balance of foreign and unique local offerings. With the recent KLIA1 renovation, I have to give credit where its due- the new bathrooms are a massive improvement! Well-designed, clean, and dry. But I cant ignore the disappointing shift in retail and dining options. Many local options have disappeared, replaced by foreign goods. Also why is alcohol and tobacco taking up a large portion of the retail space every time? I was shocked to find only one shelf of Malaysian food products in the entire terminal 1. Malaysia is a foodie havenwhy isnt KLIA showcasing its rich culinary heritage and diversity? Gone are the great local options that once served authentic dishes like kaya toast, prawn noodles and teh tarik. Instead, global chains like Starbucks and Gloria Jeans dominate the F&B spaces. Surely, theres room for more homegrown eateries that represent Malaysias incredible food culture? To add to the frustration, the monorail is still not working, and travelers have to rely on shuttle buses- slow and less efficient. And when I asked an Ask Me For Help staff member for food recommendations, she barely looked up from her phonecustomer service should be better than this. KLIA, we can do better! Support local businesses and bring back the true Malaysian experience.

TEXT: It might be more appropriate to call it Kuala Lumpur Airport rather than 'International.' While the airport is generally clean and well-lit, the transit area is underwhelming. Wi-Fi connectivity is slow, and there are limited food and retail options. A significant upgrade or expansion is needed if the airport aims to keep up with other regional hubs. Additionally, the transport pick-up experience at Terminal 2 was a nightmare. The poorly designed two-lane pick-up area created severe congestion, and we ended up waiting over an hour just to be picked up. It's unclear who was responsible for this layout, but it clearly needs a serious rethink

TEXT: Ive traveled for over 10 years, and I have NEVER seen anything as poorly managed as Kuala Lumpur Airport. We were already waiting in line at the gate, yet we STILL almost missed our flight. How is that even possible?! Turns out, they check liquids right before the gateyes, AFTER security, after duty-free, after everything. This is the most illogical, frustrating, and time-wasting system I have ever experienced. People were rushing, confused, and stressed, while staff moved at a painfully slow pace. If you value your sanity, arrive ridiculously early or just avoid this airport altogether. Absolute chaos.

TEXT: Highly Unprofessional Staff ( at least the one i dealt with ) waited almost 1.5 hours in the line there was my friend ahead of me and i was next. The lady officer she didnt asked him anything just held his passport and asked him to go to the immigration office ( He is a frequent traveller and has active visas for NZ and Uk ). I was next she saw me and told me to go too and doesnt even let me to go closer to the counter. We went to the immigration office and waited 6 hour for our number and when we were called the officer just asked me 2 questions literally 2 questions: 1 - How long you gonna stay. 2- Do you have a hotel booking. I was so heartbroken to hear these questions which the first officer could have asked me at the first place. I told the officer at the immigration about this whole scenario and she was shocked by herself and told me that she should not have sent me here and ask these questions by herself. Literally ruined my whole day almost 11 hours at the airport. Really disappointed because i was not expecting this kind of behaviour by a country which i was very excited to visit. If my review finds any person in charge please look into this matter. I know there are people who enters the country for illegal purposes like slipping or so but what about the legit tourists? TEXT: (Emerites specifically from KL).. KL is a beautiful airport, super clean, very convenient with English signs everywhere- with many options for drink and food land side before security - coffee, mcdonalds, taco bell and high end malaysian restaurants. TEXT: If you can avoid using this airport I would suggest in doing so. I have been in and out of KL a few times and each time has been a terrible experience. You will be charged fees you dont need to pay, wait in long queues and be sent to multiple stations around the airport. One particularly notable time recently was I waited so long to check in my baggage and we had told the staff our flight was soon. When I finally arrived at the counter the woman was fussing about. I asked her five times if there was an issue, and after ignoring me all those times she eventually told me my flight was boarding, so Id have to take the next flight. Once I asked her what the next time was she said 5pm, this meant I would have been stranded in Thailand with no accommodation as I needed to get a boat to where I was going. The last boat was at 6pm. After having multiple arguments with the staff a lovely man did escort us to our gate. There have honestly been multiple issues similarly at this airport, with unhelpful staff. This is coming from someone who is more than happy and patient to wait!

TEXT: For such a major international hub, the airport felt a little confusing and chaotic. We ran into the same issue two times - once on arrival (for transit) and once for departure. During arrival we wanted to switch from C Gates to A/B gates for domestic departure but it was confusing to find the directions. Exactly at the same location, during departure, we had to switch to C gates but got confused. We later realised that one of the sign boards is actually wrong. It points to an escalator upwards that goes into the shopping area. Whereas the C gates entry is exactly in the opposite direction of the sign. For an international airport this is not acceptable at all. I dont have photos, but getting confused at the same place two times is not right. We saw a few others get confused too. Apart from that there is no major security check and body scan before immigration. However this is done prior to boarding. This is not as per standard processes elsewhere wherein the detailed security check and body scan is done immediately at entry. Somehow disappointed with the airport.

TEXT: KLIA is so huge, the potential clinical coldness of the facility is cleverly softened with what appears to be an atrium of greenery. The once state of the art facilities of this Airport is marred by the breakdown of the Aerotrain system that used to provide a world class service between the terminals. The Aerotrain gates have been hidden behind dark but colourful hoarding. Opposite the hoarding are lines of waiting passengers queuing to enter the various B gates, together with their various hand carry items. With poor lighting due to the height of the dark colourd hoarding, this creates a somewhat long dark narrow somber passage that arriving visitors to Malaysia must navigate to reach the escalators to the ground level and transfer bus terminal. Any negative impressions arising from negotiating past the queuing passengers with unsettled infants and the ocassional unrestrained child darting into the crowd flow is further accentuated as one reaches the ground level and confronted by the multinational crowd chaos at the Satellite Terminal bus transfer gate. The airport employees manning the area do a great job in moving the crowd in arbitrary groups onto the waiting buses. Despite the apparent crowd chaos, these Malaysian employees at various informal "gates" manage to prevent a crowd surge and create controlled access on to the buses. These lowly front line employees are the true heroes in this situation and are living examples of the "Malaysia Boleh" can-do attitude. It's such a pity senior Airport management doesn't display a similar level of commitment in getting the Aerotrain system fixed and creating a positive first impression for international arrivals to Malaysia.

TEXT: I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines. While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight. Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member, who was shouting, to proceed to Cxx for a transfer to the arrival hall by bus. Was thinking that perhaps our flight was scheduled to park in a further lot due to multiple flights arriving around the same time,which requires us to do a short transit. Personally, I wasnt expecting to go through the hassle of having to transit from the plane to the arrival hall, taking into consideration that this was a direct flight. Anyway, still went with the flow and follow those in front since we are told to.... This information could easily be missed if people are talking or focused on finding the nearest toilet. Although the airport was large and packed with lots of shops and eateries, there are areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving/departure passengers. Would suggest the following improvements: * Rather than having a staff member shouting/giving instructions, can consider placing clear, large signage on both sides of the walkway as passengers disembark. * Provide more readily available information upon flight arrival / departure. * Consider adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay. Clear directional signs and information would make a big difference for first-time visitors like myself and would save a lot of time especially when there are so many incoming/outgoing flights day to day..... The signage for the bus transfer was unclear, and it took approximately 4-5 minutes to find the waiting point to queue for the feeder bus to the arrival hall. Upon arriving at the arrival hall, it was another 2-minute walk to reach immigration. The area was extremely crowded, with queues of 2-3 lines in a row, resulting in an hour-long wait to clear immigration. The process was very disorganized and messy, with no one managing the human traffic, possibly due to a shortage of manpower. Although the officers were friendly and efficient in clearing the queue, it would be beneficial to have crowd control/security to guide and manage the flow of passengers. Locating the correct baggage belt after clearing immigration was another challenge. The area was crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts, requiring passengers to walk near the belt to check the monitor screen. This was frustrating, especially with different groups of people surrounding the area, some looking for directions, some waiting for friends, and others searching for the right belt. We eventually found our luggage placed not far away from the luggage belt area near the exit, with a sign displaying the SQ Airlines logo on the floor. Many unclaimed bags from our flight were present, as most passengers were still stuck in immigration. The entire process, from disembarking the plane to retrieving our luggage outside the baggage claim area, was challenging. I thought we were only required to transit to the arrival hall as a one-time occurrence. However, on our return flight, we were once again required to take a short bus to the departure hall. Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient. As a tourist, the airport gives the first impression for passengers, and its organization is crucial. I hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements

TEXT: I had a deeply frustrating and disappointing experience at Kuala Lumpur Airport due to the unprofessionalism and rudeness of the staff. Upon arrival, I realized I had accidentally left my luggage in the restroom near the baggage claim. When I approached the information desk to ask for help, I received conflicting and unhelpful instructions. Some staff told me to go to the second floor, while others asked me to use an invalid boarding pass to re-enter security (which was impossible since my ticket was for a domestic flight from Kota Kinabalu). I ended up running back and forth between the second and third floors more than ten times, but no one took responsibility or provided any real assistance. Desperate, I approached a female staff member at the exit to request her help in checking the restroom for my luggage. Not only was she extremely reluctant, but she also glared at me in a hostile manner. After being persuaded by her colleague, she finally went to check the restroom. Within less than a minute, she came back and coldly told me my luggage wasnt there, claiming to have confirmed with the cleaning staff. However, this was simply not possible. Two hours later, left with no other options, I asked a passenger who hadnt exited yet to help me check the restroom. In just three minutes, they returned with my luggage. This experience was utterly unacceptable. The staffs lack of professionalism, unwillingness to help, and outright rudeness made an already stressful situation even worse. An airport should prioritize assisting passengers, not adding to their frustration. I hope the management will take serious steps to train their staff to ensure such incidents dont happen again.

TEXT: Unfortunately, my experience at Kuala Lumpur International Airport was disappointing. Here are a few points that struck me negatively: 1. Strict baggage control, but not consistent: My hand luggage was accurately weighed, and even though it was only slightly over 7kg, I was told to pay extra. At the same time, the Malaysian woman in front of me, weighing almost 8 kg, was allowed to walk away - that felt unfair. 2. Poor Signage: Some gates had no numbers, which was extremely confusing. It was difficult to find the right path. 3. Lack of seating: There were no seats at the gate, which made the wait unnecessarily tiring. 4. Inadequate Toilets: The women's restrooms were a mess - I waited in line for over 30 minutes and when it was finally my turn, they were dirty. The men apparently had enough toilets as there were no queues. Last but not least, our flight was delayed. Unfortunately, the airport was the worst I've ever been to.

TEXT: KLIA1 has undergone a number of upgrades in the past couple of years, particularly in terms of dining options on Level 5's Departure Hall (before security/immigration control) and duty-free shopping (after security/immigration control) in the main terminal. Work is still ongoing and hopefully we'll continue to see improvements in the months to come. My main problem with KLIA1 is the absence of any water refill stations at the passenger waiting area (boarding gates) after security clearance. Being a frequent flyer who's flown in and out of so many airports around the world, KLIA1 remains the only big airport that doesn't have this facility made available to passengers. I don't understand why the airport just doesn't address this issue as it's causing passengers (e.g., parents, senior travellers, etc.) so much inconvenience. Once passengers clears security, they won't access to any drinking water until they board their flight. Surely this is a shortcoming that can be easily fixed by the airport administrator...yet it remains the same month after month after month. @KLA1 - If you see this review, please provide some water refill stations for the convenience and comfort of your passengers. That's be much appreciated!

TEXT: Worst immigration experience in international airports compared to other major transit airports in Asia i.e Dubai, Doha, Istanbul and Bangkok airports. TEXT: I had two layovers at KLIA. The first time, everything went well: the airport was clean, well-organized, and especially a well-appointed prayer room, which is really appreciated by Muslim travelers. However, the second time was a completely different story, as if it weren't even the same place. As soon as you get off the plane, nothing is clear: there's almost no signage for baggage claim. It's easy to get lost, you don't know where to go. And then, surprise: you have to go through security and immigration before claiming your baggage. Completely illogical. At least let me collect my bag peacefully first! Once you're through immigration, you arrive in a huge crowd, with no smooth flow of traffic. Then you have to go through security again to get out. You board, you get off, you take a bus, you change buildings... frankly, a real hassle. Another point: the baggage counter agents are extremely strict, sometimes even abusive. If you weigh 5 kg more than you need, you pay, period, no flexibility. The prayer rooms? They used to be clean, now they're dilapidated, not maintained. Really a shame. Finally, I had a three-hour layover, I barely had time to navigate the obstacle course to get to my gate. And guess what? 40 minutes into the flight, our gate was changed from 35 to 4. Great. And then, as a Muslim, I felt uneasy. For a country I considered a brother, I had never felt so foreign. Clearly, Asian passengers are given priority. Sad to say, but I felt a real form of nationalism. In short, very disappointed. I didn't find the welcome I was hoping for in a country like Malaysia.

TEXT: Travel Tips for Kuala Lumpur: Save Money on Airport Transfers Avoid Grab e-Hailing, Especially Advance Bookings Grab drivers, particularly for advance bookings, may overcharge or provide subpar service. Instead, use Bolt for a more affordable and reliable ride. Bypass Airport Surcharges with Trains To avoid high airport ride-hailing fees, take the Express Rail Link (ERL) to Salak Tinggi station. From there, book a ride via Bolt for a significantly cheaper fare. Steer Clear of Airport Taxis Avoid taxis waiting at the airport, as they often charge exorbitant rates (RM300400). Opt for e-hailing services like Bolt, where fares to Kuala Lumpur should not exceed RM80 for a standard car or RM50 for a 4-seater. Know Your Rights with E-Hailing With e-hailing apps, pay only the fare shown in the app. If a driver demands extra payment, record their details (name, car plate number, and interaction) and report it to the nearest police station. Such behavior violates fair practices and harms Malaysias reputation. Pro Tip: Always book rides through trusted apps like Bolt for transparency and savings. Safe travels!

TEXT: I'm a Japanese tourist. I came on AirAsia via HIS. When I returned to Japan, I was constantly told to check in at the machine, and even when I went to the machine, I was asked for my reservation number. However, the document from HIS does not have a reservation number written on it. Therefore, even if you go to the counter again and say, "You can't check in using the machine!", they just insist that you "check in using the machine." So when I looked back at my HIS documents, I found a form that was difficult to understand and required me to show the staff in English that I couldn't check in using the machine. However, even if I showed them my English, the staff was insistent that I check in using the machine. After that, I managed to check in, but... Please be careful if you are going to Kuala Lumpur on HIS AirAsia. Mr. HIS, is this okay? I feel sorry for the Japanese people who will be traveling in the future.

TEXT: KLIA is an international airport that always feels like a poor budget airport that is falling apart. Ironically, it is overstaffed by an army of smiling greeters. On Sunday, 22 June 2025, we saw water dispenser stations broken and unrepaired. "Free drinks" stations abandoned, unmanned. The only smoking room in the airport is a filthy room covered in black soot: incredibly smelly, no ventilation systems, piles of ash, trash, and butts all over. Warning: Enter at your own risk. The aerotrain was being repaired, and although bus services were provided, no signs were available to passengers on where it is. Bus services from the sub terminal to the main terminal were not easy to find. Tragically, the contrast between KLIA and KLIA2 (the latter an actual budget terminal that's well designed, modern, clean, and efficient) has never been clearer. If KLIA2 is a Budget airport, then KLIA should be called a "No Budget" Airport.

TEXT: Extremely Disappointed Misleading Prices and Poor Service I had a very disappointing experience at this caf in the Malaysian International Airport. The prices displayed on the product tags were already quite high, but when I went to pay, I was suddenly asked to pay more due to additional taxes that were not shown upfront. This kind of pricing is misleading and unfair, especially in an international airport where transparency should be standard. To make matters worse, when I questioned the price difference, the staff refused to give me what I had selected unless I paid the extra hidden charges. I ended up leaving without my purchase. Travelers deserve honesty, clear pricing, and respectnot surprises at the counter. I hope airport management takes this seriously and enforces proper pricing standards. I would not recommend this caf to anyone.

TEXT: KLIA is so huge, the potential clinical coldness of the facility is cleverly softened with what appears to be an atrium of greenery. The once state of the art facilities of this Airport is marred by the breakdown of the Aerotrain system that used to provide a world class service between the terminals. The Aerotrain gates have been hidden behind dark but colourful hoarding. Opposite the hoarding are lines of waiting passengers queuing to enter the various B gates, together with their various hand carry items. With poor lighting due to the height of the dark colourd hoarding, this creates a somewhat long dark narrow somber passage that arriving visitors to Malaysia must navigate to reach the escalators to the ground level and transfer bus terminal. Any negative impressions arising from negotiating past the queuing passengers with unsettled infants and the ocassional unrestrained child darting into the crowd flow is further accentuated as one reaches the ground level and confronted by the multinational crowd chaos at the Satellite Terminal bus transfer gate. The airport employees manning the area do a great job in moving the crowd in arbitrary groups onto the waiting buses. Despite the apparent crowd chaos, these Malaysian employees at various informal "gates" manage to prevent a crowd surge and create controlled access on to the buses. These lowly front line employees are the true heroes in this situation and are living examples of the "Malaysia Boleh" can-do attitude. It's such a pity senior Airport management doesn't display a similar level of commitment in getting the Aerotrain system fixed and creating a positive first impression for international arrivals to Malaysia.

TEXT: Hands down the most inefficient airport Ive had the displeasure of travelling to 1. Pointless arriving early because your gate isnt available and you end up waiting on the tarmac without air conditioning. Not enough leeway between departing / arriving flights and no backup plan 2. You often arrive at the departures gate rather than arrivals and need to take a bus to arrivals / passport control, which is a waste of time. The new aerotrain has been out of action for over 2yrs with completion dates, unsurprisingly, being delayed several times. 3. If you havent already been severely frustrated by the first 2 points, wait till you arrive at passport control. Only 2 (max 3) of the booths are open and staff are slow, disinterested and have no desire to speed up the process, as though they revel in seeing their visitors suffer. This has been an issue for years with numerous local articles about it but efficiency and an improvement mindset simply does not exist in certain parts of the world.

TEXT: I was assaulted by a female airport passenger experience officer who attempted to physically restrain me without justification. When I demanded to file a police report, I was told I would have to go to Terminal 2something my Australian emergency passport did not permit. Despite my repeated requests, the airport police refused to take my report and instead escorted me to the immigration department. There, I was met by an aggressive and unprofessional immigration officer named Kamarudin. When I asked for his full name in writing, he refused and rudely pointed to his name badge, telling me to take a photo with my phone. The moment I did, he became enraged and began intimidating meeven going so far as to take photos of me and my passport on his personal phone. This was a blatant violation of privacy and professional conduct. **Malaysias airport authorities and immigration officers behaved in a disgusting, abusive, and unaccountable manner. Travelers beware: AVOID MALAYSIA at all costs!** **Legal Analysis** This conduct raises multiple violations under Malaysian law: 1. **Assault and Criminal Force (Penal Code Sections 350-352)** The staff member's actions in grabbing my arms and physically restraining me without consent constitutes criminal force under Section 350. Case precedent (PP v. Mohd Anuar bin Abdullah [1994] 2 MLJ 261) confirms that any intentional use of force without lawful justification meets this threshold. 2. **Wrongful Confinement (Penal Code Section 340)** The unlawful restriction of my movement within the clinic treatment room amounts to wrongful confinement. Malaysian jurisprudence establishes that detention without legal authority is punishable, particularly where no legitimate lien exists over the person. 3. **Official Misconduct** The behavior of Immigration Officer Kamarudin in: - Failing to properly address a criminal complaint - Intimidating a complainant - Improper use of personal devices to photograph sensitive documents May constitute offenses under Malaysia's official misconduct provisions. UPDATE: Malaysian Airport Management have promised a full investigation of this matter however no official response as of yet.

TEXT: Worst airport I've ever been to!!! Check-in/baggage drop took forever (despite online check-in) and there were also very long queues at the passport controls. So definitely plan plenty of time. We were there over 3 hours earlier, but in the end it was very close. There are few signs and information boards in the airport. DANGER!!! The absolute shame is the controls in front of the individual gates (no information about them beforehand). AFTER going through the duty free shop area, you will have to go through security checkpoints again and drink/throw away all of the liquids you purchased there. You even have to destroy the water you bought for the flight. In the area between security check and the plane there is no longer any possibility to buy drinks/food (nor any possibility to refill your empty bottle with water) or to go to the toilet. When I asked where I could get something to drink, all I got was an annoyed Buy in Plane. For a city like Kuala Lumpur, this airport is an absolute disgrace.

TEXT: The airport looks very fancy and all - at least Terminal 1. It is very unorganized though. We arrived extremely late from our first flight (thank you batik air) and only had 15-20min to get our connecting flight. Normally airports would provide a shuttle services, picking you from a gate to bring you to your connecting flight in time. This was not the case here, we were only told the gate number of our connecting flight, which after running to for 10min, turned out to be the wrong gate. So instead we had to take the bus to another terminal, which obviously did not give us enough time to catch our flight, so we were stuck in KL for 1 night. Additionally it is ridiculous, that there is no smoking area in the entirety of terminal 1. So if you are stuck here for a while you have to go all the way to terminal 2, into one of the most disgusting smoking rooms Ive witnessed in my life (no ventilation at all, might as well just walk in and breath twice and youve already passively smoked a carton of cigarettes). Really disappointing for such a modern (only t1) and large airport.

TEXT: Worst transit experience ever. TEXT: Worst immigration experience in international airports compared to other major transit airports in Asia i.e Dubai, Doha, Istanbul and Bangkok airports. Immigration in the country took more than 1.5 hours and system was down so they had to do manual entries. On the way back. Immigration took more than 2 hours. I had to request few people to let go of their turn so that I don't miss my flight. Only one counter for a queue of about 50 people(Normally takes 30 mins at other airports, however, the Malaysia made sure 50 people took 2 hours). There was this lady at the counter. She took more than 30 mins on one couple! FGS either accept or reject. Very un progressional behavior by the immigration staff. This long wait made me miss my visit to chocolate shops as only 20 mins were left after the immigration clears. Moreover, for international departures you have to take a bus to another lounge. Which is weird for such a developed country. The shops inside are nice and many food options are available. Mosque is available on 3rd level. Have to search for it or ask for directions from the staff. If some one wishes to connect a domestic flight directly with the international keep at least 3 hours buffer. Always book within the same literary. Keep at least 2 hours for the immigration clearance. Such a pathetic and slow service. Even countries such as Pakistan and KSA have better immigration services. The flight was ready to depart after boarding and other checks have been completed. However, it took more than 10 minutes for our plane to get permission to get on the runway. Malaysia wants to attract tourists ? Please invest in your airport and immigration services. Thank you

TEXT: KLIA is an international airport that always feels like a poor budget airport that is falling apart. Ironically, it is overstaffed by an army of smiling greeters. On Sunday, 22 June 2025, we saw water dispenser stations broken and unrepaired. "Free drinks" stations abandoned, unmanned. The only smoking room in the airport is a filthy room covered in black soot: incredibly smelly, no ventilation systems, piles of ash, trash, and butts all over. Warning: Enter at your own risk. The aerotrain was being repaired, and although bus services were provided, no signs were available to passengers on where it is. Bus services from the sub terminal to the main terminal were not easy to find. Tragically, the contrast between KLIA and KLIA2 (the latter an actual budget terminal that's well designed, modern, clean, and efficient) has never been clearer. If KLIA2 is a Budget airport, then KLIA should be called a "No Budget" Airport.

TEXT: It's the capital airport of a big country It's hot because they turned on the air conditioner. The bathroom is dirty because it's a toilet like a regular restaurant bathroom~ There's only one smoking room before the baggage checkpoint, but there's no signage. On top of that, it's not cleaned and it's very dirty Despite being a large airport with a lot of transfers, there aren't enough chairs to rest and wait, and there are only paid massage chairs! And there's a lot of shopping. Malaysia is a beggar who's become rich~ Of course, the price is expensive, and even that's almost nonexistent after security. Smokers, you must stop by the smoking room before security. If you go all the way to the corner before the P and Q gates, you'll find the smoking room. After security, it's crowded with people waiting~ It's hard to find a chair~ The structure and area are very stuffy, and it's hard to find any amenities. This is the worst experience. It's not even worth one star!

TEXT: Was about to miss our flight, our flight was supposed to be in gate L but our boarding pass said it was gate P, when we heard the announcer saying "last call", we didn't know where our gate was supposed to be since it was our first time in Malaysia and we didn't think about reading or seeing any of the screens because we didn't think the gate would change so abruptly and so far away, we asked the staff there and they weren't much help, it was like they DIDNT CARE if we missed our flight. Service is 0/10, but the rest is quite decent.

TEXT: I had the worst experience in this airport for travelling. This looks fancy but very old school. Restaurant not enough air con at night time. Sweating when eating Very confusing direction or procedure given. I was required to transferred here from overseas to KKIA (domestic) i was not required to take my lugguage while I gone through the customs here. Then walked all the way from international to domestic from the international building. But then I was required to "enter" the Malaysia border again while I was in KKIA (I took domestic) with my checked in luggage and scanning my index fingers When i went back from KK to KL, I only required to go thru the custom once at KKIA. I was expecting to go thru the domestic building so I can get some local products. Then my hand luggage was required to go thru x ray just at the gate when leaving from KL to overseas. My flask was full of water. But it was not required to empty out. And no airline staff at the gate just b4 boarding to check the boarding priority. Airline still tier off the ticket manually. As I thought I can walk thru, so I followed the sign. I realised I couldn't walk thru after 5 mins later. Then I walked back and realised the sign was directed incorrectly neat gate G section. One pointing left and the other sign pointed right. I saw few customers including aircrew staff were confused and didn't know which way to go. Further, the staff was staring at me while was brusing teeth at the washroom at 6am. I realised she's waiting to clean my spot after I finished brushing. She either come back rather than just staring at me. I felt so unconfmy and I was the only passenger there. I went other less modern airport like ho chi Ming city or in Istanbul. Where still have better experience than in Malaysia

TEXT: Drinking water is a major issue at the airport and there are several reviews mentioning this but nothing has changed. You are not allowed to take your water beyond security which is understandable but how can you not have water filling stations or even bottled water for people waiting to board? It's quite disappointing and shocking, and can be a big issue especially for elderly passengers and those with health issues. In a hot and humid climate, access to drinking water is essential. Unfortunately, there are no water refill stations or bottled water available after security. If there is a flight delay, passengers are left waiting for hours without water. I've been to several airports and never had this issue, just look at Singapore airport where there are water refill facilities everywhere. I strongly urge the airport authorities to look into this and provide better facilities for water access after security. The current conditions are simply unacceptable especially for the elderly and those with health issues.

TEXT: I had one of the worst airport experiences at Kuala Lumpur International Airport, Terminal 2. Upon arrival, we were met with confusing procedures and zero proper guidance on how to complete the entry process. The Arrive app they require is completely unnecessary, buggy, and slows everything down. There was no one clearly assigned to assist passengers, and the process made no sense. To make matters worse, we approached a uniformed police officer for help, who rudely dismissed us and refused to offer any kind of support. His tone was aggressive, unprofessional, and completely inappropriate for someone representing airport security. Instead of helping travelersmany of whom were clearly confused and exhaustedhe seemed more interested in scolding people. The lack of signage, the useless app, and untrained or unwilling staff made the whole arrival process feel hostile and disorganized. For a country that depends on tourism, this kind of treatment is unacceptable. I wont be flying into KLIA Terminal 2 again anytime soon.

TEXT: This airport made me never want to come back to Malaysia. Who designed this place?! First, the walk from the plane to immigration and baggage claim was unbelievably long. Ive traveled through many large airports, but Ive never had to walk this much just to reach my luggage. I could overlook that but what came next was even worse. After collecting our bags and passing immigration, we were forced to walk through (GET THIS!) A MALL to get to the exit. Yes, a literal mall where every airport in the world you'd be checking your transportation to finally leave. After a long flight, the last thing anyone wants is to be dragged through a maze of stores just to leave the airport. It felt like a cash grab, not a travel hub. We finally made it out and were relieved to see Grab was available (were used to it from Thailand). But when we booked a ride, the wait time was 35 minutes! There was a huge, overcrowded Grab waiting area with screens showing incoming car plates, clearly, demand was way beyond what the airport could handle. Tired and frustrated, we gave up on Grab, hoping to catch a bus instead. But we werent allowed to buy tickets until exactly 12 AM, which was also the listed departure time of the bus, because it's too late now to buy tickets (15 minutes ahead). We were told the bus would leave even after 12. The whole thing felt disorganized and unclear and the wait time seemed same as the Grab and the destination station is not even close to the hotel. In the end, we paid over double the Grab fare to take a regular taxi, just to get the hell out of there. Oh and did I mention that the airport wifi is not available once you finish immigration? I had such a hard time to book the Grab and check information and chat with my airbnb host because there was no wifi after immigration, because there's a freakin' mall between the airport and the exits!!! This airport is a logistical mess and a terrible first impression of Malaysia. I've never thought an airport would affect my will to visit a country but here we are.

TEXT: Arriving: Immigration for arrivals took too long! The officers works so slowly and the poor internet connection in this area is not helping either. It took us long enough to complete immigration to the point that our bags were no longer in the conveyor belt/shown on screen. Pick up location of ride hailing (Grab) was easy at Level 1. Departure: Check in counters are spread out making it not too crowded/congested. Immigration for departure is quicker and easier. However, there's a security screening for customs departure that was separated with at-gate security check. I would say this is very inefficient as you need to check your bags twice and once you have cleared security you practically cannot go out to the retail area. This also lead to congestion during Gate Open as people would avoid coming to it and come as late as possible. Security at the gate is so slow. In addition, the post-security gate is a nightmare with neither water stations nor proper toilet! There seems to be no signs of priority boarding based on group but rather by seats (not sure if this is an MH or KLIA problem). Retail space is decent with great tax-free goods options and decent restaurant selections. One thing to appreciate: the toilets (in retail & public) areas are clean and equipped with jet showers.

TEXT: Extremely Poor Accessibility & Lack of Compassion I brought my elderly grandmotherwho requires a wheelchair and has dementiato the airport, and the accessibility experience was appalling. When I approached the front desk to request a wheelchair, I was told to go all the way to the check-in area at the end of the terminal first. How is someone supposed to leave a person with dementia alone while they go fetch a wheelchair? We had no choice but to walk the entire distance, which completely defeats the purpose of offering assistance in the first place. To make matters worse, the check-in counter we needed was right at the end of the row. If my grandmother had truly been immobile, she wouldve had no way to reach that point on her own. Imagine if she were a solo disabled travellerwhat would have happened then? Even more disappointing was the staff attitude. There were six front counter staff chatting among themselves, not a single smile, not a trace of compassion or initiative. It felt like basic empathy and responsibility were missing entirely. Accessibility should not be an afterthought, and neither should kindness.

TEXT: The immigration officers are rude and disrespectful. Not only do they seem uneducated, they are pretty disgusting in their treatment of travellers. Many Malays receive English education from elementary school but still can't speak English properly! How does that work? To be honest, it felt like the staff were completely uninterested in their job, and some even seemed to resent being there. If you don't want to be bullied, shouted at or ignored when asking questions during an already stressful flight trip, then avoid this airport at all cost! I was here on a 3 hour transit trip and within a span of those hours the amount of bullying and incompetence I observed was horrifying. Trust me this airport doesn't discriminate, nearly everyone of all nationalities and ethnicities feel the brunt of their hostility. Also, within 3 hours, the gate changed like 6 times! I have been to many major airports before, never faced something like this. What really stood out was the slogan displayed upon arrival: We hope youve enjoyed our Malaysian Hospitality. Frankly, this felt more like an empty promise than a reflection of the experience I had. A service should speak for itself, but in this case, it was clear that overcompensating with slogans only highlights the gap between what is advertised and what is actually delivered. Given this experience, I will never visit Malaysia again and I certainly won't be encouraging my friends or family to visit. Avoid countries that do not respect and appreciate tourist coming to help their economy!

TEXT: For such a major international hub, the airport felt a little confusing and chaotic. We ran into the same issue two times - once on arrival (for transit) and once for departure. During arrival we wanted to switch from C Gates to A/B gates for domestic departure but it was confusing to find the directions. Exactly at the same location, during departure, we had to switch to C gates but got confused. We later realised that one of the sign boards is actually wrong. It points to an escalator upwards that goes into the shopping area. Whereas the C gates entry is exactly in the opposite direction of the sign. For an international airport this is not acceptable at all. I dont have photos, but getting confused at the same place two times is not right. We saw a few others get confused too. Apart from that there is no major security check and body scan before immigration. However this is done prior to boarding. This is not as per standard processes elsewhere wherein the detailed security check and body scan is done immediately at entry. Somehow disappointed with the airport.

TEXT: I had the worst experience in this airport for travelling. This looks fancy but very old school. Restaurant not enough air con at night time. Sweating when eating Very confusing direction or procedure. I was required to transferred here from overseas to KKIA (domestic) i was not required to take my lugguage while I gone through the customs here. Then walked all the way from international to domestic from the international building. But then I was required to "enter" the Malaysia border again while I was in KKIA (I took domestic) with my checked in luggage and scanning my index fingers When i went back from KK to KL, I only required to go thru the custom once at KKIA. I was expecting to go thru the domestic building so I can get some local products. Then my hand luggage was required to go thru x ray just at the gate. My flask was full of water. But it was not required to empty out. And no airline staff at the gate just b4 boarding to check the boarding priority. As I thought I can walk thru, so I followed the sign. I realised I couldn't walk thru after 5 mins later. Then I walked back and realised the sign was directed incorrectly neat gate G section. One pointing left and the other sign pointed right. I saw few customers including aircrew staff were confused and didn't know which way to go. Further, the staff was staring at me while was brusing teeth at the washroom at 6am. I realised she's waiting to clean my spot after I finished brushing. She either come back rather than just staring at me. I felt so unconfmy and I was the only passenger there. I went other less modern airport like ho chi Ming city or in Istanbul. Where still have better experience than in Malaysia

TEXT: The customs officers have a very bad attitude, they are very arrogant and unprofessional. I went there several times to visit friends and often saw them making things difficult for foreigners. They asked us to provide a lot of information and proofs and we had to know what they were going to ask and see at all times. As long as we showed fear or didn't understand, we would be made to feel very difficult. I was also made to feel difficult myself. When the automatic customs clearance just came out, there were many problems. We could only queue up for the staff to review. The speed was slow and they didn't open more gates. The staff next to them were also in a hurry to get off work and didn't pay much attention to your need for help. I strongly recommend that you apply for MDAC online

TEXT: Ive traveled through KLIA countless times over the years, and it has always stood out for its cleanliness, smooth check-in process, and efficient security checks. The architecture, inspired by Malaysian, Islamic, and natural elements, is a beautiful highlight. But what truly made KLIA special was its balance of foreign and unique local offerings. With the recent KLIA1 renovation, I have to give credit where its due- the new bathrooms are a massive improvement! Well-designed, clean, and dry. But I cant ignore the disappointing shift in retail and dining options. Many local options have disappeared, replaced by foreign goods. Also why is alcohol and tobacco taking up a large portion of the retail space every time? I was shocked to find only one shelf of Malaysian food products in the entire terminal 1. Malaysia is a foodie havenwhy isnt KLIA showcasing its rich culinary heritage and diversity? This seem to now be engulfed by the blandness of foreign cafe franchises, croissants and cakes. Would be delightful to have more local options! Gone are the great local options that once served authentic dishes like kaya toast, prawn noodles and teh tarik. Instead, global chains like Starbucks and Gloria Jeans dominate the F&B spaces. Surely, theres room for more homegrown eateries that represent Malaysias incredible food culture? To add to the frustration, the monorail is still not working, and travelers have to rely on shuttle buses- slow and less efficient. And when I asked an Ask Me For Help staff member for food recommendations, she barely looked up from her phonecustomer service should be better than this. KLIA, we can do better! Support local businesses and bring back the true Malaysian experience.
processed_text: ive travel countless time year always stand cleanliness smooth checkin process efficient security check architecture inspire malaysian islamic natural element beautiful highlight truly make special balance foreign unique local offering recent klia1 renovation give credit due new bathroom massive improvement welldesigned clean dry cant ignore disappointing shift retail din option many local option disappear replace foreign good also alcohol tobacco take large portion retail space every time shock find one shelf malaysian food product entire terminal 1 malaysia foodie havenwhy isnt showcasing rich culinary heritage diversity seem engulf blandness foreign cafe franchise croissant cake would delightful local option go great local option serve authentic dish like kaya toast prawn noodle teh tarik instead global chain like starbucks gloria jean dominate fb space surely there room homegrown eatery represent malaysias incredible food culture add frustration monorail still work traveler rely shuttle bus slow less efficient ask ask help staff member food recommendation barely look phonecustomer service good good support local business bring back true malaysian experience

TEXT: I gave it one star because I can't give it one... This is the worst airport I've ever flown through, and yet I've flown through quite a few around the world: Singapore, Jakarta, Surabaya, Bangkok; I've never seen such a bad airport. There's no signage, the staff is unfriendly and absolutely unhelpful. The organization is incredibly dismal. And no one does anything to make your life easier, not to mention the distances, which are unreasonable. Nothing in this airport, in fact, is either pleasant or makes your life easier; quite the opposite. I know of a more expensive ticket, but above all, avoid going through this airport if you have the choice. This is the third time I've flown through here, and I hope it's the last.

TEXT: KLIA2 is by far the most disappointing terminal, starting with the immigration service, which completely kills any desire to ever return here. TEXT: I am writing to provide feedback on my recent experience flying to KLIA via Singapore Airlines. While I generally appreciate the quality of service on Singapore Airlines flights, I was disappointed with the airport experience at KLIA, especially considering this was not a budget flight. Although the airport was large and packed with lots of shops and eateries, there are areas that could be improved to facilitate smoother transit for arriving/departure passengers. Personally, I wasnt expecting to go through the hassle of having to transit from the plane to the arrival hall, taking into consideration that this was a direct flight. Upon arrival, after disembarking from the plane, we were directed by a staff member, who was shouting, to proceed to Cxx for a transfer to the arrival hall. This information could easily be missed if people are talking or focused on finding the nearest toilet. I tried to console myself, thinking that perhaps our flight was scheduled to park in a further lot due to multiple flights arriving around the same time. Anyway, just go with the flow and follow those in front since we are told to .... Would suggest the following improvements: * Rather than having a staff member shout instructions, you can consider placing clear, large signage on both sides of the walkway as passengers disembark. * Provide more readily available information upon flight arrival / departure. * Consider adjusting the volume of the announcement speaker with loud and clear information in English, Chinese, and Malay. Clear directional signs and information would make a big difference for first-time visitors like myself and would save a lot of time especially when you have so many incoming/outgoing flights day to day..... The signage for the bus transfer was unclear, and it took approximately 4-5 minutes to find the waiting point to queue for the feeder bus to the arrival hall. Upon arriving at the arrival hall, it was another 2-minute walk to reach immigration. The area was extremely crowded, with queues of 2-3 lines in a row, resulting in an hour-long wait to clear immigration. The process was very disorganized and messy, with no one managing the human traffic, possibly due to a shortage of manpower. Although the officers were friendly and efficient in clearing the queue, it would be beneficial to have crowd control/security to guide and manage the flow of passengers. Locating the correct baggage belt after clearing immigration was another challenge. The area was crowded, and there were only three to four luggage belts, requiring passengers to walk near the belt to check the monitor screen. This was frustrating, especially with different groups of people surrounding the area, some looking for directions, some waiting for friends, and others searching for the right belt. We eventually found our luggage placed not far away from the luggage belt area near the exit, with a sign displaying the SQ Airlines logo on the floor. Many unclaimed bags from our flight were present, as most passengers were still stuck in immigration. The entire process, from disembarking the plane to retrieving our luggage outside the baggage claim area, was challenging. I thought we were only required to transit to the arrival hall as a one-time occurrence. However, on our return flight, we were once again required to take a short bus to the departure hall. Furthermore, there were no water dispensers available after passing through the inspection gate, which was inconvenient. As a tourist, the airport gives the first impression for passengers, and its organization is crucial. I hope this feedback will be taken into consideration for future improvements

TEXT: Ive traveled through KLIA countless times, and it has always impressed me with its cleanliness, smooth check-in process, and efficient security checks. The architecture, inspired by Malaysian, Islamic, and natural elements, remains a stunning highlight. But what truly made KLIA special was its balance of international and uniquely local offerings- something that now seems to be fading. With the recent KLIA1 renovation, I have to give credit where its duethe new bathrooms are a huge improvement! Well-designed, clean, and dry. But the retail and dining experience has taken a disappointing turn. Many local options have disappeared, replaced by foreign goods. And once again, alcohol and tobacco seem to dominate the retail spacewhy so much of it? I was shocked to find just one shelf of Malaysian food products in the entire terminal 1. Malaysia is a food paradisewhy isnt KLIA celebrating this? Instead, the vibrancy of local flavors is being replaced by the bland sameness of foreign caf chains, croissants, and cakes. More AUTHENTIC local options would be a delight!- especially for those leaving home and craving one last nasi lemak or kuey teow or teh tarik or curried roti? Once, travelers could enjoy authentic Malaysian dishes like kaya toast, prawn noodles, and teh tarik. Now, the F&B scene is overrun by global chains like Starbucks and Gloria Jeans. Surely, KLIA can do better by making space for homegrown eateries that showcase Malaysias rich culinary diversity?- take a page out of Jakarta or Singapore airport. To add to the frustration, the monorail is still out of service (Ive lost count how long Ive waited), forcing travelers to rely on slow and inefficient shuttle buses. And when I asked an Ask Me For Help staff member for food recommendations, she barely looked up from her phone. Customer service should be better than this! KLIA, lets do better! Support local businesses and bring back the authentic Malaysian experience to travellers. P.S. if youre ever at the Satellite building of KLIA terminal 1, I highly recommend checking out the Jungle Boardwalk I always look forward to visiting it if my Gate is located there.

TEXT: A large, modern, yet manageable airport. Unfortunately, I have to give it only 3 stars because immigration and passport control took a very long time. I'm not used to this in Asian metropolises, and I wish the airport administration could come up with something here.

TEXT: The airport is huge. From Airline 1, you need to take a shuttle bus to Airline 2, but the bus goes incredibly fast and there are no handrails, so be careful. We were stuck in the line with the human linemen when we went through customs, so we had to wait in the line again when we returned home. Unfortunately, the human linemen were incredibly slow and inattentive, so the wait was incredibly long. So, we had to go through the machine at customs. It was also very crowded when we went inside to eat. I thought fast food would be faster, but the line at Burger King, ordering and picking up, can take an hour. It's not even fast food!? In the end, we didn't have time to eat and had to take it to go. There wasn't a single store in the airport that we could explore. The inspection process here is also very unique. You can bring water through the first checkpoint, but you have to go through the X-ray machine again before boarding the plane. You can't bring water this time. You're directly on the plane. There's no place to fill up your water or use the vending machines. My throat was really sore before the in-flight meal arrived. If you want to enjoy a leisurely stroll and eat, it's recommended to arrive 3-5 hours early. We arrived 3 hours early and were still in such a mess.

TEXT: KLIA Main Terminal is definitely looking tired now. Arrivals process is laborious, through a dark Immigration area (with a long queue almost always) into a dingy baggage claim area. Then prepare to run the gauntlet of taxi hawkers. Toilets are filthy. Car rental area is in an even dirtier forgotten part of a car park, well away from the terminal. Horrendous and frightening journey for single females to negotiate to. At least LCCT has Car rental booths actually in the terminal at arrivals. Update January 2023 and nothing has improved about KLIA 1. The car rental office area is nothing short of a discusting, hot & humid, car fume filled enclosed area. Staffed by people who need to be motivated away from their phones to serve you. That just completes the whole slow, painful experience of a dark and miserable KLIA and a sorry welcome to Malaysia. A national disgrace that needs to be addressed from the miserable gate staff, immigration & customs officials, to the customer facing staff throughout. Unfortunately people like myself have no choice but to suffer KLIA regularly.
