TEXT: There are many things to improve at this airport. There are twice as many security checks, passport checks, and boarding passes as at a Western airport. Just to give an example, the security process (where they check your water and all that) is right in front of the boarding gate. This means that once you've passed through security, you can't buy anything, including the toilet, water, etc. Aside from the inconvenience for travelers, it means underutilization of the machines for the airport, because they're only used when there's a flight at that gate, and fewer sales opportunities, because you're confined to that room for at least an hour and a half before the flight departs, waiting to actually board. They have a lot to learn from their neighbors in Singapore, a little further south.

TEXT: This airport made me never want to come back to Malaysia. Who designed this place?! First, the walk from the plane to immigration and baggage claim was unbelievably long. Ive traveled through many large airports, but Ive never had to walk this much just to reach my luggage. I could overlook that but what came next was even worse. After collecting our bags and passing immigration, we were forced to walk through (GET THIS!) A MALL to get to the exit. Yes, a literal mall where every airport in the world you'd be checking your transportation to finally leave. After a long flight, the last thing anyone wants is to be dragged through a maze of stores just to leave the airport. It felt like a cash grab, not a travel hub. We finally made it out and were relieved to see Grab was available (were used to it from Thailand). But when we booked a ride, the wait time was 35 minutes! There was a huge, overcrowded Grab waiting area with screens showing incoming car plates, clearly, demand was way beyond what the airport could handle. Tired and frustrated, we gave up on Grab, hoping to catch a bus instead. But we werent allowed to buy tickets until exactly 12 AM, which was also the listed departure time of the bus, "because it's too late now to buy tickets" (15 minutes ahead). We were told the bus would leave even after 12. The whole thing felt disorganized and unclear and the wait time seemed same as the Grab and the destination station is not even close to the hotel. In the end, we paid almost triple the Grab fare to take a regular taxi, just to get the hell out of there. Oh and did I mention that the airport wifi is not available once you finish immigration? I had such a hard time to book the Grab and check information and chat with my airbnb host because there was no wifi after immigration, because there's a freakin' mall between the airport and the exits!!! TEXT: I'm giving it 1 star for the following reasons: T1-> the security check only takes place immediately before boarding. This means that if you buy drinks before then (which you take with you on long-haul flights), you have to return them! Which is completely pointless! Furthermore, there's nothing to eat after baggage drop-off and passport control (which you want to get through as quickly as possible). Furthermore, there are no restrooms after the security check, so you'll wait about an hour for boarding plus a good 45 minutes until you're in the air to use a restroom... I've never seen anything like it, and I've been to many countries/continents.

TEXT: This airport made me never want to come back to Malaysia. Who designed this place?! First, the walk from the plane to immigration and baggage claim was unbelievably long. Ive traveled through many large airports, but Ive never had to walk this much just to reach my luggage. I could overlook that but what came next was even worse. After collecting our bags and passing immigration, we were forced to walk through (GET THIS!) A MALL to get to the exit. Yes, a literal mall where every airport in the world you'd be checking your transportation to finally leave. After a long flight, the last thing anyone wants is to be dragged through a maze of stores just to leave the airport. It felt like a cash grab, not a travel hub. We finally made it out and were relieved to see Grab was available (were used to it from Thailand). But when we booked a ride, the wait time was 35 minutes! There was a huge, overcrowded Grab waiting area with screens showing incoming car plates, clearly, demand was way beyond what the airport could handle. Tired and frustrated, we gave up on Grab, hoping to catch a bus instead. But we werent allowed to buy tickets until exactly 12 AM, which was also the listed departure time of the bus, "because it's too late now to buy tickets" (15 minutes ahead). We were told the bus would leave even after 12. The whole thing felt disorganized and unclear and the wait time seemed same as the Grab and the destination station is not even close to the hotel. In the end, we paid almost triple the Grab fare to take a regular taxi, just to get the hell out of there. And also, the airport wifi is not available once you finish immigration! I had such a hard time to book the Grab taxi and check information and chat with my airbnb host because there was no wifi after immigration, in any airport that's when wifi is needed!! But here there's a freakin' mall between the airport and the exits!!! I've never had this much hastle and wasted time to manage to exit an airport. This airport is a logistical mess and a terrible first impression of Malaysia. I've never thought an airport would affect my will to visit a country but here we are.

TEXT: Edit: upon arrival as of June 2025, they removed auto entry now for foreign passports and only locals can go through them- what a waste of automated gates! KLIA is a massive airport, but as of December 2024, its still undergoing some upgrading works, so not everything is fully operational (has been going on for the past year). Shops and dining options are still quite limited despite the airport's large size, which is a bit disappointing for travelers looking to explore or relax before their flights. On the positive side, for certain passport holders, the biometric scanning at immigration makes the process quick and efficient, which is a welcome convenience. However, the baggage scanning process remains tediousyoure required to scan your bags multiple times, such as when entering immigration and again when heading to your gate. Personally, this feels unnecessarily repetitive, but theres little travelers can do about it. Overall, KLIA has potential, and hopefully, the ongoing upgrades will bring noticeable improvements to both the facilities and passenger experience in the near future.

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) in Malaysia is a major aviation hub known for its modern infrastructure and significant passenger capacity. It features two main terminals: KLIA1 (Main Terminal) for full-service airlines and KLIA2, which is the worlds largest terminal dedicated to low-cost carriers. Both terminals provide extensive amenities such as check-in counters, retail outlets, duty-free shops, lounges, and a range of dining options. Despite its impressive size and facilities, passenger experiences at KLIA show a mixed picture. Some travelers appreciate the airports efficiency, particularly with business class services that offer quick access to lounges and smooth security checks. The connectivity is good, with efficient transportation options like the KLIA Ekspres train linking the airport to Kuala Lumpur city center in under 30 minutes, plus taxis and buses are readily available. However, there are notable complaints that affect the overall impression. Passengers frequently cite poor staff behavior, long queues, and confusion during boarding and baggage checks, often describing staff as unfriendly or inattentive. Some criticize the immigration process, mentioning inconvenient requirements and poor assistance, especially for transit passengers. Food and beverage options, particularly in KLIA2, have received negative reviews for being limited, expensive, or insufficient for the passenger volume. Seating areas can be inadequate during peak times, and the indoor climate control sometimes falls short, making waiting uncomfortable. In terms of infrastructure, KLIA offers modern and clean facilities, with well-organized terminals and a spacious layout. The addition of automated train systems within KLIA1 and a skybridge in KLIA2 has improved passenger movement. The airport continues to be recognized for service quality by industry bodies, but in practice, staff performance and customer service remain areas needing improvement. Overall, KLIA is a modern and strategically important airport that provides extensive amenities and connectivity but is let down by inconsistent service quality and operational challenges that impact traveler satisfaction.Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) in Malaysia is a major and modern airport serving millions yearly, with two main terminals: KLIA1 for full-service airlines and KLIA2 dedicated to budget carriers. Both terminals feature extensive amenities including retail outlets, duty-free shops, lounges, and various dining options, supported by advanced infrastructure like automated trains and skybridges for smooth passenger transfers. While the airport excels in its size, facilities, and connectivityoffering quick transportation options like the KLIA Ekspres train to Kuala Lumpurit has garnered mixed overall reviews from travelers. Many praise KLIA1 for efficient and smooth security and boarding processes, especially for business class passengers. However, there are widespread complaints about staff attitude, with reports of unfriendly and inattentive personnel, chaotic queues, and confusing procedures that dampen the experience. Other common issues include limited food and beverage options, especially in KLIA2, overcrowded seating areas, and inconsistent indoor climate control, making waiting uncomfortable during peak times. Some travelers also find the immigration and transfer processes cumbersome, with poor assistance and odd paperwork requirements for transit passengers. Despite these challenges, KLIA maintains a clean and modern terminal environment with generally well-maintained facilities. It has received industry awards for its infrastructure and immigration service, but passenger experiences suggest that improving customer service and operational management is needed to match the airports world-class status. In summary, KLIA offers comprehensive facilities and good connectivity as Malaysias primary international gateway but is hampered by service inconsistencies and operational issues that impact passenger satisfaction.

TEXT: I used Terminal 2 (KLIA2), which is mainly used by low-cost carriers. There are many restaurants just outside the arrival gate, and many of them are open 24 hours a day, which is very convenient. There are many seats where you can charge your phones, and some stores have Wi-Fi. The food court a little further back to the left of the arrival gate has very cheap prices. The supermarket called JayaGROCER is also cheap. When you arrive, you can get to the city center by taking the KLIA Express, a limited express train, which is cheap and fast. However, there are restrictions on departure times, so if you want to get around easily, you should use the car dispatch service "Grab" or a taxi. The cheapest option is by far the bus. There is a luxurious lounge that accepts Priority Pass (3-hour system) at the back of LEVEL3, where the boarding gate is located, to the left. I saw a few people sleeping on the ground on the boarding gate floor at night. However, the downside is that it is a very long walk to the boarding gate. After the initial simple baggage inspection, it takes about 20 minutes to walk to the gate.

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport, also known as KLIA. In addition to the main airport building, there's a separate, cross-shaped airport building for arrivals and boarding. If you use this building for departures and arrivals, you'll need to take the free shuttle train for immigration and boarding. For Koreans, this system is similar to Incheon International Airport. TEXT: It is the largest airport in Malaysia and one of the busiest airports in Asia. The airport was built at a cost of up to 3.5 billion USD and was inaugurated on June 27, 1998. Japanese architect Kisho Kurokawa designed this airport. The airport is 50 km from the capital Kuala Lumpur. In 2009, this airport served 29.6 million passengers (lower than the expected 35 million passengers). This airport has a 130 m high air traffic control tower, the second highest among air traffic control towers (only after the tower at Suvarnabhumi International Airport in Bangkok) with 2 runways 60 m wide and more than 4,000 m long, capable of serving 120 flights/hour. According to the plan, this airport will have 4 runways. Terminal capacity in phase 2 to 2012 is 35 million passengers/year and in phase 2 to 2012 is 45 million passengers/year. #KuaLaLumPurAirport

TEXT: Airport Terminal 1 boasts modern upgrades to its luggage drop, check-in, immigration processes, and overall size. It is located approximately 60 minutes from Kuala Lumpur by car, or a quicker 45-minute journey via express train. However, there are a few areas for potential improvement. 1. Currently, there is a lack of a dedicated food court. While some cafes and pantries offer refreshments, the options are limited to cold food, and the only Burger King and other food options are situated at Gate C, inconveniently distant from other gates. The travel time to Gate C from other gates is 15 minutes one-way by bus. 2. Seating is somewhat limited. 3. Entertainment options for children and families could be expanded. 4. The washrooms could be enhanced by providing tissue paper in the hand-wash areas. 5. Duty-free prices may be considered slightly higher than in some other countries. The airport does offer complimentary Wi-Fi access for all passengers and provides adequate restroom facilities.

TEXT: I used Terminal 2 (KLIA2), which is mainly used by low-cost carriers. There are many restaurants just outside the arrival gate, and many of them are open 24 hours a day, which is very convenient. There are many seats where you can charge your phones, and some stores have Wi-Fi. The food court a little further back to the left of the arrival gate has very cheap prices. The supermarket called JayaGROCER is also cheap. When you arrive, you can get to the city center by taking the KLIA Express, a limited express train, which is cheap and fast. However, there are restrictions on departure times, so if you want to get around easily, you should use the car dispatch service "Grab" or a taxi. The cheapest option is by far the bus. There is a luxurious lounge that accepts Priority Pass (3-hour system) at the back of LEVEL3, where the boarding gate is located, to the left. I saw a few people sleeping on the ground on the boarding gate floor at night. However, the downside is that it is a very long walk to the boarding gate. After the initial simple baggage inspection, it takes about 20 minutes to walk to the gate.

TEXT: This is Kuala Lumpur International Airport. There is free Wi-Fi at the airport, so if you haven't purchased a SIM card yet, please use the free Wi-Fi at the airport first. The airport here is designed a little differently, with departure and arrival terminals connected. I was arriving that day, but following the directions, I passed the departure lobby and duty-free shops and went to immigration. I was then directed to C5, and took a bus to the arrival immigration. If you don't know the way, it's easy to get lost, so if you get lost, be sure to ask a nearby staff member for directions right away. The airport itself is large, so it took about 40 minutes from arrival to baggage claim. It's about an hour's drive from here to Kuala Lumpur city. Malaysia is a fusion of various cultures, including Chinese, Islamic, and Buddhist.

TEXT: The airport is very large. Arrivals on a Tuesday evening were relatively smooth. Famous restaurants like Hua Yang and Hai Jiao Ren are located at the airport. I highly recommend checking them out first, as the lines at restaurants downtown are incredibly long. Departures on Saturday morning were a bit more chaotic, with incredibly crowded people and numerous check-in counters. They weren't divided by flight. From previous travel experience, children can't check in at the check-in counter. So, initially, we kept looking for a human check-in counter. We asked three staff members, each with a different explanation. This wasted a lot of time. It just so happened that our flight was delayed by an hour, otherwise we might have missed it. The restaurant in the airport lobby was incredibly crowded. After finally getting a table, it took another 30 minutes. We later discovered there were still many shops and restaurants after customs. Furthermore, baggage screening at customs required two checks, and the distance from customs to the boarding gate was quite long. On the way back, I recommend exploring and eating at the gate. You don't have to crowd the outermost area; the restaurants inside are just like the airport lobby. Best of all, they were less crowded, allowing you to leisurely wait for your flight. We had some fast food recommended by a local. The cola looked like root beer, served from a machine that looked like draft beer. It was quite interesting. The pancakes were surprisingly deliciouslarge, crispy, and generously prepared.

TEXT: KLIA is a decent and well-maintained airport, with clear signages and good connectivity to the city via the KLIA Express. The airport offers a range of facilities, shopping, and dining options, and generally handles immigration and security procedures efficiently. However, compared to airports like Singapores Changi, I find KLIA lacks a certain warmth and polish. The overall design feels a bit dated, and some areas can be quite empty or underwhelming in terms of atmosphere. While functional, it doesnt offer the same level of comfort, innovation, or world-class amenities that Changi is known for. Still, for travel in and out of Malaysia, KLIA does its job well. Its just not my favorite airport in the region.

TEXT: The airport is clean. When you get off at Terminal 1, follow the arrivals signs and continue walking until you reach the terminal where you must take the elevator. You must take the elevator to get to the main terminal. There are many duty-free shops nearby. It might seem strange because it's different from Korea, but don't worry. Just keep going straight and take the elevator. Once you get off, go straight for a bit and then descend to the basement. You'll need to go down to the arrivals hall. The problem here is that the wait for immigration can sometimes exceed an hour. The line for complete immigration is incredibly long. You'll need to pass through here to collect your luggage and exit. It can be a little confusing, but just remember that you have to take the elevator, walk a bit, and then descend to the basement. Have a nice trip.

TEXT: Edit: upon arrival as of June 2025, they removed auto entry now for foreign passports and only locals can go through them- what a waste of automated gates! KLIA is a massive airport, but as of December 2024, its still undergoing some upgrading works, so not everything is fully operational (has been going on for the past year). Shops and dining options are still quite limited despite the airport's large size, which is a bit disappointing for travelers looking to explore or relax before their flights. On the positive side, for certain passport holders, the biometric scanning at immigration makes the process quick and efficient, which is a welcome convenience. However, the baggage scanning process remains tediousyoure required to scan your bags multiple times, such as when entering immigration and again when heading to your gate. Personally, this feels unnecessarily repetitive, but theres little travelers can do about it. Overall, KLIA has potential, and hopefully, the ongoing upgrades will bring noticeable improvements to both the facilities and passenger experience in the near future.

TEXT: Information for Turkish friends: After disembarking on August 7, 2025, it took us about an hour to get to the Grapla hotel. These procedures include going through passport control, collecting luggage, converting money, and going to Gate 5 on the lowest floor. When you arrive, you first fill out a form using a QR code. This information is sent to your email address. Then, when you go through passport control, you fill it out and you enter the country without any problems. I recommend getting training before you arrive. The airport's Wi-Fi works very well. It's very easy to get to the Grapla city center or your hotel. It's not very practical to exchange money at the airport. You can exchange $20 if you have a small amount of cash with you. Grapla is level 1, door 5.

TEXT: Very nice airport with a great viewing area. Plenty of food places and the souvenir shops sold items at good prices. They were of course higher than at shops, but for an airport, they were good. The baggage drop for British airways took a very long time. If flying with Malaysian airways and some other Asian airlines, there was practically no queue as it was self service. Then there was immigration, which opened up to more shops. After immigration, the bags were kind of scanned, but this wasn't security. This then opens up to more shops and restaurants. Only 1 out of the 4 water fountains worked at this point and the water was only for consumption in this area, because you then pass through security when the gate opens. After security, there are just seats. No water and no toilets. I found there to be a lot of walking around to the next point, but there many shops making it a good experience

TEXT: Wasn't really my cup of tea but more than adequate. Not sure why people are complaining though - not every airport is 5 stars. The terminals are split between buildings but at least the transfer buses are always available and the distance is short. There is ample lighting in the terminals and the areas that are dim are perfect for sleeping in. Gates are clearly signposted and the amount of walking is not too challenging. Not a lot to do here as shop selections are really minimal. Interestingly, KL was the place to shop back in the 1980s. Not sure what happened over the years but I'm suspecting the main flow of passengers transit through the Middle East (eg Dubai). The only irritating thing I found was unruly children banging on the piano in terminal C. 1 star for the parents!

TEXT: So first of all: the airport is big!!! The usual recommendation to be at the airport at least 3 hours before departure should be strictly adhered to. There are multiple floors and the terminal with Gates C is outside and requires an additional bus ride. Positive: There is a large selection of warm food and drinks in the Arrival Hall early in the morning. The Departure Hall is on the top floor and is very cluttered and full of people. It's important to stay calm and ask for the airline at the information counter. The signage at the counters is small and you would have to look through all of them until you find the right one. (If you fly with Etihad Airways... it's counter A.) It's best to check in online... it saves time. There were initially only a few counters open and some passengers had a lot of suitcases that were all weighed and labeled. The same thing happens with hand luggage. As soon as you have got rid of your checked baggage, it is best to go to immigration without hesitation and then you can stand in line again. Then you go through the first check where only hand luggage is checked. Positive: This happened very quickly. Anyone who has one of Gates C on their boarding pass now goes to the bus transfer. Short queues, even shorter bus ride. Arrived at Gate C, last chance to go to the toilet or get something to drink. Then stand in line at the security checkpoint. But it goes quite quickly even if there are a lot of people waiting in line. Negative: Arriving passengers have to go through those waiting when they get off the plane. You wait for boarding in a cool but relatively comfortable environment without a toilet or the opportunity to buy something to drink or eat. Addendum to entry: Arrive at Gate C, then take the bus to the main terminal with little delay. Immigration went very quickly, but there was nothing going on in the morning. However, the wait for the luggage took longer again. In the Arrival Hall there are clean toilets, ATMs, food including Burger King and various options to buy a Malaysian SIM card that is really worth the money. Arrival and departure airport - KL Sentral quickly and without pro

TEXT: So first of all: the airport is big!!! The usual recommendation to be at the airport at least 3 hours before departure should be strictly adhered to. There are multiple floors and the terminal with Gates C is outside and requires an additional bus ride. Positive: There is a large selection of warm food and drinks in the Arrival Hall early in the morning. The Departure Hall is on the top floor and is very cluttered and full of people. Here it is important to keep calm and it is best to ask for the airline at the information counter. The signage at the counters is small and you would have to look through all of them until you find the right one. (If you fly with Etihad Airways... it's counter A.) It's best to check in online... it saves time. There were initially only a few counters open and some passengers had a lot of suitcases that were all weighed and labeled. The same thing happens with hand luggage. As soon as you have got rid of your checked baggage, it is best to go to immigration without hesitation and then you can stand in line again. Then you go through the first check where only hand luggage is checked. Positive: This happened very quickly. Anyone who has one of Gates C on their boarding pass now goes to the bus transfer. Short queues, even shorter bus ride. Arrived at Gate C, last chance to go to the toilet or get something to drink. Then stand in line at the security checkpoint. But it goes quite quickly even if there are a lot of people waiting in line. Negative: Arriving passengers have to go through those waiting when they get off the plane. You wait for boarding in a cool but relatively comfortable environment (no comparison to Abu Dhabi of course!) without a toilet or the opportunity to buy something to drink or eat. Addendum to entry: Arrive at Gate C, then take the bus to the main terminal with little delay. Immigration went very quickly, but there was nothing going on in the morning. However, the wait for the luggage took longer again. In the Arrival Hall there are clean toilets, ATMs, food including Burger King and various options to buy a Malaysian SIM card that is really worth the money. Arrival and departure: Airport - KL Sentral with KLIA Express quickly and without any problems. If you want to go to the TBS bus station, take the KLIA Transit. Conclusion: You collect a lot of steps at this airport and stand in a lot of queues. And you need time!!! The signage is sometimes very good, sometimes inconsistent and sometimes confusing. There are enough toilets and also lots of large and small shops and duty free shops.

TEXT: KLIA has room for improvement in several areas. The air conditioning was not cold enough, making the airport feel quite stuffy. The water dispensers were not functioning, which was inconvenient for travelers looking to refill their bottles. Signage is another major issue, particularly for McDonald's. While there's a visible kiosk near Jamie Oliver, the other McDonald's outlet is poorly marked and easy to miss, hidden behind people and lacking clear directions. The KFC location is also not well-indicated, making it difficult for first-time visitors to find. On a positive note, the toilet cleanliness is commendable. The cleaning staff are diligent, ensuring the facilities are spotless after each use. This level of hygiene is definitely appreciated and sets a good standard for airport maintenance.

TEXT: Disappointed with KLIA1s Renovation Wheres the Local Flavor? Ive traveled through KLIA countless times over the years, and it has always impressed me with its cleanliness, easy check-in process, and efficient security checks. The architecture, influenced by Malaysian, Islamic, and natural elements, is a highlight. But what made KLIA truly special was the presence of local food, beverages, and products. With the recent renovation of KLIA1, I have to say I am very pleased with the new improved bathrooms- better designed, clean and dry :) But Ive noticed a disappointing shiftmany local offerings have been replaced by foreign goods, with alcohol and tobacco dominating the retail space. I was shocked to find only one shelf of Malaysian food products in the entire terminal! Malaysia is a foodie paradise with so much to offer- why isnt KLIA showcasing it? Previously, there were great local cafs serving authentic Malaysian dishes like prawn noodles and teh tarik. Now, all I see are global chains like Starbucks and Gloria Jeans. Cant there be more homegrown F&B options for travelers to experience real Malaysian flavors? To top it off, the monorail is still not working (shuttle busses are the alternate) and my attempt to ask an Ask Me For Help staff member about food options was met with disinterestshe was too busy scrolling on her phone to assist me properly. KLIA, we can do better! Support local businesses and bring back the Malaysian experience!

TEXT: Airport Terminal 1 boasts modern upgrades to its luggage drop, check-in, immigration processes, and overall size. It's located approximately 60 minutes from Kuala Lumpur by car, or a quicker 45-minute journey via express train. However, there are a few areas for potential improvement. 1. Currently, there is a lack of a dedicated food court. While some cafes and pantries offer refreshments, the options are limited to cold food, and the only Burger King is situated at Gate C, inconveniently distant from other gates. 2. Seating is somewhat limited. 3. Entertainment options for children and families could be expanded. 4. The washrooms could be enhanced by providing tissue paper in the hand-wash areas. 5. Duty-free prices may be considered slightly higher than in some other countries. The airport does offer complimentary Wi-Fi access for all passengers and provides adequate restroom facilities.

TEXT: Edit: upon arrival, they removed auto entry now for foreign passports and only locals can go through them- what a waste of automated gates! KLIA is a massive airport, but as of December 2024, its still undergoing some upgrading works, so not everything is fully operational (has been going on for the past year). Shops and dining options are still quite limited despite the airport's large size, which is a bit disappointing for travelers looking to explore or relax before their flights. On the positive side, for certain passport holders, the biometric scanning at immigration makes the process quick and efficient, which is a welcome convenience. However, the baggage scanning process remains tediousyoure required to scan your bags multiple times, such as when entering immigration and again when heading to your gate. Personally, this feels unnecessarily repetitive, but theres little travelers can do about it. Overall, KLIA has potential, and hopefully, the ongoing upgrades will bring noticeable improvements to both the facilities and passenger experience in the near future.

TEXT: Malaysia will celebrate Merdeka Day at the end of August 2025. The airspace around KLIA (Kuala Lumpur International Airport) will be temporarily closed from 8:00 AM to 12:00 PM daily from August 26th to 31st. Flights departing or arriving during this period may be adjusted! To this end, Malaysia Airlines has announced on its website that departure and arrival times for certain flights will be adjusted. For details on affected flights, please visit their website; I've only captured a partial screenshot! I think other airlines will be affected to some extent, so please check in advance Malaysia will celebrate Merdeka's Independence Day at the end of August, and the airspace around KLIA (Kuala Lumpur International Airport) will be temporarily closed from 8 am to 12 noon every day from 8.26 to 8.31. The small partners who leave/arrive during this time, the flight may be adjusted! To this end, Malaysia Airlines has indicated in official website that the departure and arrival times of the corresponding flights will be adjusted. You can go to their official website to check the specific flight tips, and I only took a partial screenshot! ! ! I think other airlines will be affected to some extent. Please confirm in advance.

TEXT: Ive traveled through KLIA countless times over the years, and it has always impressed me with its cleanliness, easy check-in process, and efficient security checks. The architecture, influenced by Malaysian, Islamic, and natural elements, is a highlight. But what made KLIA truly special was the presence of local food, beverages, and products as it seems now all international airport have become repetitive and similar with their offerings of international luxury brands, familiar franchises, etc. With the recent renovation of KLIA1, I have to say I am very pleased with the new improved bathrooms- better designed, clean and dry :) But Ive noticed a disappointing shiftmany local offerings have been replaced by foreign goods, with alcohol and tobacco dominating the retail space. I was shocked to find only one shelf of Malaysian food products in the entire terminal! Malaysia is a foodie paradise with so much to offer- why isnt KLIA showcasing it? Previously, there were great local cafs serving authentic Malaysian dishes like prawn noodles and teh tarik. Now, all I see are global chains like Starbucks and Gloria Jeans. Cant there be more homegrown F&B options for travelers to experience real Malaysian flavors? To top it off, the monorail is still not working (shuttle busses are the alternate) and my attempt to ask an Ask Me For Help staff member about food options was met with disinterestshe was too busy scrolling on her phone to assist me properly. KLIA, we can do better! Support local businesses and bring back the Malaysian experience!

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is more than just a travel hub its a complete experience that blends efficiency, comfort, and a touch of Malaysian hospitality. From the moment you arrive, the design of the airport stands out. The main terminal building is bright, spacious, and airy, with a modern architectural style that still feels warm and welcoming. The satellite building, connected by the Aerotrain, adds to the sense of scale and convenience, making it easy for passengers to transfer between terminals. In terms of navigation, KLIA is well signposted, with clear directions in English and Malay. Even for first-time visitors, its relatively simple to find immigration, baggage claim, and onward connections. While the airport is large, the layout is intuitive, and staff members are friendly and ready to assist if you ever feel lost. Immigration and security checks are usually smooth and efficient, although during peak travel hours there can be queues nothing unusual for an airport of this size. The facilities here are excellent. There is a wide variety of food and drink options catering to every budget, from local Malaysian dishes (which I highly recommend if you have time) to international fast food, coffee shops, and sit-down restaurants. Shopping is also a highlight the duty-free selection is extensive, with everything from cosmetics and electronics to Malaysian souvenirs and delicacies. If youre in transit or have a long layover, KLIA makes the wait comfortable. There are plenty of lounges, seating areas, and even a capsule hotel where you can book a few hours of rest. The airport also has prayer rooms, child-friendly facilities, and smoking zones, which shows that it caters thoughtfully to different types of travelers. Free Wi-Fi is available, though it can sometimes be a little slow, so its good to have mobile data as backup. Getting to and from the airport is extremely convenient. The KLIA Ekspres train is one of the best features it takes just under 30 minutes to reach KL Sentral in the city center, and its fast, comfortable, and reliable. Taxis and ride-hailing services are also widely available, and buses provide budget-friendly options. One thing to keep in mind is that the airport is quite large, so be prepared to walk a fair bit between gates or from security to boarding. For some travelers, this can be tiring, but the clear signage and moving walkways help a lot. Overall, KLIA is a world-class airport that balances efficiency with comfort. Its clean, modern, and well-maintained, but it also has a distinct cultural touch that reminds you youre in Malaysia. Whether youre arriving, departing, or transiting, KLIA leaves a positive impression and sets the tone for a great journey.

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KUL) is a major international airport serving Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Here are some key points about the airport: Airport Information - *Location:* Kuala Lumpur International Airport is located about 45 kilometers south of Kuala Lumpur city center. - *Terminals:* The airport has multiple terminals, including Terminal 1, Terminal 2, and the KLIA2 terminal for low-cost carriers. Amenities and Services - *Dining:* The airport offers a wide range of dining options, including restaurants, cafes, and snack bars. - *Shopping:* There are various shops selling duty-free products, souvenirs, and other items. - *Currency Exchange:* Currency exchange services are available at the airport. - *Transportation:* The airport offers various transportation options, including taxis, buses, trains, and car rentals. Airlines and Destinations - *Malaysia Airlines:* Kuala Lumpur International Airport is the hub for Malaysia Airlines. - *International Flights:* The airport offers flights to various international destinations in Asia, Europe, the Middle East, and Oceania. Tips for Travelers - *Plan Ahead:* Arrive at the airport with plenty of time to spare before your flight. - *Check Flight Status:* Check the status of your flight before heading to the airport. - *Know the Airport Layout:* Familiarize yourself with the airport's layout to make the most of your time.

TEXT: A seamless experience at KLIA, one of the best airports in Southeast Asia Traveling through Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is always comfortable and efficient. From the moment you arrive, you're greeted by a modern, clean, and well-organized facility, where it's clear that passenger comfort and overall smooth operation are a priority. Passport control is very streamlined, especially if you're eligible to use the automated e-gates (it's worth checking if your passport is listed). The entire process is quick and hassle-free, which is a great start to any international trip. Once you clear immigration, the airport is spacious and very well-maintained. The gates for Area C are easily reached via a regular shuttle train that departs after passport control. Everything is well signposted and easy to navigate. There are tons of options for both shopping and dining, so you'll never feel bored while you wait. From duty-free shops to local and international restaurants, there's plenty to discover before boarding. A helpful tip: KLIA is approximately 45 minutes from downtown Kuala Lumpur (KLCC) if you travel early in the morning when there's no traffic. During the day, it's a good idea to allow between one and one hour and ten minutes, depending on congestion. We traveled from Terminal 1, which serves many major international airlines such as Etihad (A), Emirates (B), Turkish Airlines (M), and several others. It's advisable to check your gate assignment in advance, as it can change shortly before departure! We had the opportunity to try Illy coffee near Gate C13. Although there was quite a line, service was quick once the order was placed. The staff was friendly and helpful. However, the coffee left something to be desired. The Americano and cappuccino had a strange taste, somewhat resembling burnt marshmallows. Still, the sourdough bakery selection was quite good, with fresh and satisfying options for pre-flight snacks. Overall, KLIA is an excellent international hub. Clean, efficient, and well-thought-out. If they improve the coffee quality a bit in some areas, it would be near perfect. Still, I would definitely transit or depart from KLIA again. Highly recommended for both frequent travelers and first-time flyers. Smooth Experience at KLIA - One of Southeast Asia's Best Airports! Traveling through Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is always a comfortable and efficient experience. From the moment you arrive, you're met with a clean, modern, and well-organized facility that clearly prioritizes both passenger comfort and operational efficiency. Passport control is a breeze, especially if you're eligible to use the automated e-gates (check if your passport is listed beforehand). The process is quick and fuss-free... a great start to any international journey Once you pass immigration, you'll find the airport impressively spacious and well-maintained. The departure gates at Concourse C are accessible by a smooth and regular train shuttle after passport control; very simple with clear signage throughout Retail and dining options are abundant, so you'll never feel bored during your wait. From duty-free shops to local and international eateries, there's plenty to explore while waiting for your flight. A small note on timing KLIA is located around 45 minutes from KLCC (city centre) early in the morning when traffic is light. However, during daytime hours, I recommend allowing at least 1 hour to 1 hour 10 minutes for the journey, depending on traffic conditions!!! We flew out of Terminal 1, which handles many major international carriers including Etihad (A), Emirates (B), Turkish Airlines (M) and several others. Its worth double-checking your gate assignment as signage can sometimes be updated close to departure...

TEXT: I often use this airport when traveling to Southeast Asia or South Asia. If I remember correctly, it was designed by Kurokawa Kisho. Terminal 1 is home to many Malaysia Airlines flights. Terminal 2 has a larger number of LCCs. It's a fairly large airport, and Terminals 1 and 2 are quite far apart. You can take the shuttle bus or the high-speed train. It takes a while. Terminal 1 also has a satellite terminal, and there is an unmanned train between the main terminal and the satellite terminal. This takes just a moment. Terminal 1 also has a full range of duty-free shops and a wide selection of restaurants. At airport prices, though. I was happy to see an airport piano. The airport staff were all friendly and welcoming. The exhibits inside the airport were also elaborate. When I visited, they were themed around Malacca. The center is set up like a garden. There are plenty of chairs, including some comfortable ones where you might want to take a nap.

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KUL) is a major international airport serving Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Here are some key points about the airport: Airport Information - *Location:* Kuala Lumpur International Airport is located about 45 kilometers south of Kuala Lumpur city center. - *Terminals:* The airport has multiple terminals, including Terminal 1, Terminal 2, and the KLIA2 terminal for low-cost carriers. Amenities and Services - *Dining:* The airport offers a wide range of dining options, including restaurants, cafes, and snack bars. - *Shopping:* There are various shops selling duty-free products, souvenirs, and other items. - *Currency Exchange:* Currency exchange services are available at the airport. - *Transportation:* The airport offers various transportation options, including taxis, buses, trains, and car rentals. Airlines and Destinations - *Malaysia Airlines:* Kuala Lumpur International Airport is the hub for Malaysia Airlines. - *International Flights:* The airport offers flights to various international destinations in Asia, Europe, the Middle East, and Oceania. Tips for Travelers - *Plan Ahead:* Arrive at the airport with plenty of time to spare before your flight. - *Check Flight Status:* Check the status of your flight before heading to the airport. - *Know the Airport Layout:* Familiarize yourself with the airport's layout to make the most of your time.

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is honestly one of my favorite airports, and Ive been here countless times! Every visit feels seamless and well-organized, from check-in to boarding. The facilities are top-notchspacious lounges, clean restrooms, and plenty of charging stations, which is such a lifesaver when you have long layovers. I also love the variety of dining and shopping options; whether Im craving local Malaysian cuisine, international favorites, or just a quick coffee, theres always something to satisfy. The airport staff are friendly and helpful, making every transit smooth and stress-free. What really stands out is the overall vibeKLIA manages to feel modern, efficient, and welcoming all at once. Even after many trips, I still find little things to enjoy and appreciate here. Truly, KLIA sets a high standard for airports, and I always look forward to my next visit!

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) A Major Asian Hub with Smooth Connectivity | Travel Consultant Review As a travel consultant, I often recommend KLIA as a transit point or entry to Southeast Asia. Here's a breakdown of the experience: Highlights: Modern Infrastructure KLIA is clean, spacious, and well-designed. The terminalsKLIA (Main Terminal) and KLIA2 (Low-cost Terminal)are efficiently connected via train and shuttle. Connectivity Excellent connectivity via ERL (Express Rail Link) to central Kuala Lumpur in just ~30 minutes. Clear signage in English and Malay makes navigation easy for international travelers. Immigration & Security Immigration can be quick during non-peak hours, but delays are possible during busy times. Security is generally smooth and well-organized. Shopping & Amenities KLIA offers duty-free shops, premium brands, local crafts, and great food courts. Muslim prayer rooms, child play areas, lounges, and clean restrooms add to the comfort. Hospitality & Help Desks Friendly and professional staff. Help counters and digital info kiosks are helpful, especially for first-time visitors. Things to Keep in Mind: KLIA2 is separate and caters mostly to AirAsia and budget carriersplan accordingly if you have a connecting flight between KLIA and KLIA2. Transit times between gates can be long; allow extra time, especially for international connections. Consultants Tip: Use the Plaza Premium Lounge for long layoversits affordable and well-equipped. Download the Malaysia Airports app for real-time updates and gate information. Overall Rating: 8.5/10 A world-class airport that balances efficiency with Malaysian hospitalityideal for smooth international transit or as a gateway to explore Malaysia.

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is located in Sepang, Selangor, about 45 km from the capital city. This is the largest and most important airport in Malaysia. The project officially opened in 1998, serving both domestic and international flights. KLIA has two main terminals: Terminal 1 and Terminal 2 (klia2). Traveling between terminals can be done by Aerotrain or shuttle bus. From Kuala Lumpur to the airport, passengers often choose the KLIA Ekspres train with a travel time of about 28 minutes. The space inside the airport is modern, spacious and clean. The signs are clear, convenient for finding the gate and doing procedures. This is a major air gateway, welcoming millions of visitors to Malaysia every year.

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur Airport (KLIA)** is Malaysia's main international aviation hub and one of the busiest airports in Southeast Asia. Located in Sepang, Selangor, about 50 kilometers from Kuala Lumpur city center, it offers modern facilities and convenient transport links. KLIA is divided into a main terminal (KLIA1) and a low-cost terminal (KLIA2), which serve traditional and low-cost airlines. The main terminal is elegantly designed and fully functional, integrating modern architecture and Malay cultural elements. It has a spacious waiting room and natural lighting to make passengers feel comfortable and relaxed. The airport offers a variety of convenient facilities, including a variety of restaurants, duty-free shops, gift shops and premium brand counters to meet the shopping and dining needs of travelers.

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is one of the most convenient and well-organized airports in Southeast Asia. It serves as Malaysias main international gateway and is located about 45 minutes from the city center. Whether youre arriving, departing, or just on a layover, KLIA offers a smooth and pleasant airport experience. The airport is spacious, clean, and well-designed with clear signage and friendly staff ready to assist travelers. One of the things people really appreciate about KLIA is the wide variety of food options. If youre in the mood for a quick bite, youll find familiar names like Burger King, perfect for grabbing fast food before your flight. There are also other cafs, local eateries, and international food chains to suit every taste. KLIA is also a great place to do some last-minute shopping. There are plenty of duty-free stores, offering everything from snacks and souvenirs to premium items. For those who love fragrances, youll find perfume shops from various global brands, all neatly arranged and reasonably priced. Whether youre traveling for business or leisure, KLIA provides everything you need from comfort and convenience to dining and shopping. Its a great first and last impression of Malaysia, and a reminder of how far the country has come in terms of global connectivity and modern infrastructure

TEXT: Sprawling, shiny hub that juggles 57M passengers yearly with the grace of a seasoned ringmaster. Terminals 1 & 2 buzzing like a futuristic bazaar. Pampers with luxe lounges (try Plaza Premium for a nap pod!), while KLIA2 keeps budget travelers happy with AirAsias dominance and cheap eats like Nasi Lemak Wanjo. Pro tips: Breeze through immigration with the new biometric e-gates if youre a frequent flyer register on arrival! The KLIA Ekspres (28 minutes to KL Sentral) is your wallet-friendly escape from taxi touts. Grab a SIM from the Tune Talk kiosk for instant 5G, and hit the revamped Eraman Duty-Free for local gems like Boh Tea or durian chocolate (yes, its a thing). Hungry? Myeongdong Topokki in KLIA2 serves spicy Korean bites to fuel your layover. Free Wi-Fis solid, but download the MySejahtera app for seamless travel updates. Watch out for peak hour crowds (mornings are manic). KLIAs a smooth operator, blending efficiency with that Malaysian charm, just dont linger too long at the chocolate stalls! "Selamat berjalan-jalan" (Happy Travels)

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is one of the most modern and efficient airports in Southeast Asia. From the moment you arrive, it offers a clean, organized, and traveler-friendly experience. Pros: Well-Designed & Spacious The terminal layout is intuitive with plenty of signs in multiple languages. The ceilings are high and the design is elegant, giving a sense of openness and calm. Immigration & Security Generally smooth and well-managed, especially for Malaysian passport holders. International travelers may experience a short wait, but the staff are polite and efficient. Facilities Plenty of clean toilets, prayer rooms, baby care rooms, and seating areas. Charging stations are available in key waiting areas. Shopping & Dining A good range of duty-free shops, restaurants, and local Malaysian food options. Prices are reasonable for an international airport. Transport Options KLIA Ekspres train to the city is fast and reliable (just 28 minutes to KL Sentral). Taxis, e-hailing (Grab), and buses are also readily available. Free Wi-Fi Stable and fast for short browsing or communication.

TEXT: I recently traveled from Bali to Mumbai with a layover at Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) via Malaysia Airlines, and I had a smooth and pleasant experience. TEXT: I used Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) It is a vast airport that can be said to be the gateway to Malaysia, and it was a very comfortable airport that combined modern facilities with a tropical atmosphere The terminal is large, the signs are easy to understand, and there is plenty of English, so even those who are not used to traveling abroad can feel at ease There are plenty of duty-free shops and restaurants, so I was able to spend my time before departure and transfer without getting bored There is also a food court where you can enjoy local food, so you can enjoy your last Malaysian gourmet before departure In addition, the toilets, lounges, and Wi-Fi environment are well-equipped, so I was able to spend my time comfortably before and after a long flight [Recommended points] A spacious, clean, and modern airport Plenty of dining, shopping, and relaxation facilities Convenient and easy to understand for transit Experience Malaysian vibes until the end of your trip It was a comfortable airport, perfect for the start of your trip or for a moment before returning home I'll be sure to use it again when I visit Malaysia

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA)** is Malaysia's main international aviation hub and one of the busiest airports in Southeast Asia. Located in Sepang, Selangor, approximately 50 kilometres from Kuala Lumpur city centre, it offers modern facilities and convenient transport links. KLIA is divided into a main terminal (KLIA1) and a low-cost terminal (KLIA2), which serve traditional and low-cost airlines. The main terminal is elegantly designed and fully functional, integrating modern architecture and Malay cultural elements. It has a spacious waiting area and natural lighting to make passengers feel comfortable and relaxed. The airport offers a variety of convenient facilities, including a variety of restaurants, duty-free shops, souvenir shops and high-end brand counters to meet the shopping and dining needs of travelers.

TEXT: After my recent experience at Nice and CDG airports (in France), I'm continuing my chronicle of everything a traveler has to go through! TEXT: Flying out or landing in KLIA2? Heres a quick dose: KLIA2 opened in 2014 to replace the old LCCT (Low-Cost Carrier Terminal)and is now the home base for airlines like AirAsia and is one of the biggest purpose-built low-cost terminals in the world! Yes..so big you can literally walk 2km (I think its more..) inside to get to your boarding gate.so be sure to wear comfy shoes or your best cushioned disco sandals (or bring a scooter?) Gateway@KLIA2 is connected to the terminal, packed with food, stores & even a grocery! Its like a mini shopping mall with gates, to the extent you could arrive with just credit and dress up from top to bottom complete with rolling luggage to rock the day. Flying via KLIA2 makes you an early bird even if you are a marathon runner (kudos to you if you have pre-checked in and zero check in luggage). Get there at least 3 hours earlyimmigration lines can be sneaky long or check into the many aerohotels or capsule hotels (sama-sama) for a place to crash. Enjoy the lounge or play the Malaysian national sportand explore vast culinary from nasi lemak to homeland FuiYoh uncle Rogers fried rice and delicate steamed dumplings from din tai fung or A&W and McDonalds, doze on a massage chair or people watch till you daze if you have plenty of time to kill. Currency exchanges are all around (RHBs rate is not bad) KLIA Ekspres from KL Sentral gets you there fast & comfy. E-hailing is a buzz with tonnes of queues at level 1 Whether youre heading off to new adventures or coming home to Nasi Lemak, KLIA2s got your back.

TEXT: KLIA Main Terminal: Designed by Japanese architect Kisho Kurokawa and opened in 1998, its architectural style combines modern technology with tropical rainforest elements. Skybridge and Transfer Design: The main terminal and satellite terminal are connected by a high-speed train (Aerotrain), creating a seamless flow of traffic. TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is undoubtedly one of the most modern and efficient hubs in Southeast Asia. The facilities are spacious, clean, and well-signposted, making travel easy, even for those unfamiliar with the area. Connections to the city center via the KLIA Express train are fast and convenient, allowing passengers to reach the capital in just 30 minutes. The dining scene is also varied, with local and international options available in both the arrivals and departures areas. The security and customer service staff are generally friendly and helpful, and immigration controls are usually relatively smooth if you don't arrive during rush hour. However, one of KLIA's major weaknesses is the limited number of rest areas for passengers in transit or with long layovers. Although there are some VIP lounges and capsule hotels with a fee, the airport doesn't offer enough comfortable public areas for reclining or sleeping, something that is sorely lacking when it comes to overnight waits or long connections. Improvements in this area would make the overall experience much more pleasant. In short, an efficient and modern airport, but one that needs to consider the comfort of travelers in transit more.

TEXT: Sprawling, shiny hub that juggles 57M passengers yearly with the grace of a seasoned ringmaster. Terminals 1 & 2 buzzing like a futuristic bazaar. Pampers with luxe lounges (try Plaza Premium for a nap pod!), while KLIA2 keeps budget travelers happy with AirAsias dominance and cheap eats like Nasi Lemak Wanjo. Pro tips: Breeze through immigration with the new biometric e-gates if youre a frequent flyer register on arrival! The KLIA Ekspres (28 minutes to KL Sentral) is your wallet-friendly escape from taxi touts. Grab a SIM from the Tune Talk kiosk for instant 5G, and hit the revamped Eraman Duty-Free for local gems like Boh Tea or durian chocolate (yes, its a thing). Hungry? Myeongdong Topokki in KLIA2 serves spicy Korean bites to fuel your layover. Free Wi-Fis solid, but download the MySejahtera app for seamless travel updates. Watch out for peak hour crowds (mornings are manic). KLIAs a smooth operator, blending efficiency with that Malaysian charm, just dont linger too long at the chocolate stalls! "Selamat berjalan-jalan" (Happy Travels)

TEXT: Modern, well-connected, and spacious international airport Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is one of Southeast Asias most impressive airports. Its clean, well-organized, and offers plenty of services for both international and domestic travelers. The airport is split into two terminals: KLIA (main terminal) for full-service airlines and KLIA2 for budget carriers like AirAsia. A free shuttle bus runs between them frequently, which is super convenient. The main terminal (KLIA) is spacious with high ceilings and even includes a small indoor rainforesta really unique touch! Immigration and customs can be slow during peak hours, but the staff are generally friendly and helpful. Signage throughout the airport is clear, and its easy to find your way around. KLIA2 is more modern in terms of retail options, offering a wide variety of shops, restaurants, and lounges. It has more of a shopping mall feel and is perfect if you have a long layover. However, walking distances can be long, so plan accordingly. The KLIA Ekspres train makes travel to and from downtown Kuala Lumpur quick and easy (about 30 minutes), which is a major plus. Some downsides include occasional delays at immigration and certain gates that require shuttle buses, which isnt ideal for tired travelers. Still, overall, KLIA is a great airportefficient, comfortable, and a solid first impression of Malaysia.

TEXT: Flying out or landing in KLIA2? Heres a quick dose: KLIA2 opened in 2014 to replace the old LCCT (Low-Cost Carrier Terminal)and is now the home base for airlines like AirAsia and is one of the biggest purpose-built low-cost terminals in the world! Yes..so big you can literally walk 2km (I think its more..) inside to get to your boarding gate.so be sure to wear comfy shoes or your best cushioned disco sandals (or bring a scooter?) Gateway@KLIA2 is connected to the terminal, packed with food, stores & even a grocery! Its like a mini shopping mall with gates, to the extent you could arrive with just credit and dress up from top to bottom complete with rolling luggage to rock the day. Flying via KLIA2 makes you an early bird even if you are a marathon runner (kudos to you if you have pre-checked in and zero check in luggage). Get there at least 3 hours earlyimmigration lines can be sneaky long or check into the many aerohotels or capsule hotels (sama-sama) for a place to crash. Enjoy the lounge or play the Malaysian national sportand explore vast culinary from nasi lemak to homeland FuiYoh uncle Rogers fried rice and delicate steamed dumplings from din tai fung or A&W and McDonalds, doze on a massage chair or people watch till you daze if you have plenty of time to kill. Currency exchanges are all around (RHBs rate is not bad) KLIA Ekspres from KL Sentral gets you there fast & comfy. E-hailing is a buzz with tonnes of queues at level 1 Whether youre heading off to new adventures or coming home to Nasi Lemak, KLIA2s got your back.

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) A Major Asian Hub with Smooth Connectivity | Travel Consultant Review As a travel consultant, I often recommend KLIA as a transit point or entry to Southeast Asia. Here's a breakdown of the experience: Highlights: Modern Infrastructure KLIA is clean, spacious, and well-designed. The terminalsKLIA (Main Terminal) and KLIA2 (Low-cost Terminal)are efficiently connected via train and shuttle. Connectivity Excellent connectivity via ERL (Express Rail Link) to central Kuala Lumpur in just ~30 minutes. Clear signage in English and Malay makes navigation easy for international travelers. Immigration & Security Immigration can be quick during non-peak hours, but delays are possible during busy times. Security is generally smooth and well-organized. Shopping & Amenities KLIA offers duty-free shops, premium brands, local crafts, and great food courts. Muslim prayer rooms, child play areas, lounges, and clean restrooms add to the comfort. Hospitality & Help Desks Friendly and professional staff. Help counters and digital info kiosks are helpful, especially for first-time visitors. Things to Keep in Mind: KLIA2 is separate and caters mostly to AirAsia and budget carriersplan accordingly if you have a connecting flight between KLIA and KLIA2. Transit times between gates can be long; allow extra time, especially for international connections. Consultants Tip: Use the Plaza Premium Lounge for long layoversits affordable and well-equipped. Download the Malaysia Airports app for real-time updates and gate information. Overall Rating: 8.5/10 A world-class airport that balances efficiency with Malaysian hospitalityideal for smooth international transit or as a gateway to explore Malaysia.

TEXT: KLIA is a very spacious airport with a layout that still feels impressive. The building itself is quite old, but it has been reasonably well maintained. Public facilities, including the toilets, are generally clean, and there are plenty of shops and tenants to explore, which makes long layovers or transit times less boring. That said, a little modernization or refurbishment would make the airport feel more up-to-date. Staff presence is quite visible, and while some are very professional and well-trained, there are still others who could benefit from additional training to enhance service consistency. Overall, KLIA is a good international hub, but as an airportessentially a service productcontinuous improvements in both facilities and staff service quality are key to maintaining a world-class standard.

TEXT: After my recent experience at Nice and CDG airports (in France), I'm continuing my chronicle of everything a traveler has to go through! And what a joy to arrive at Kuala Lumpur airport Here everything is practical, easy, and when you don't know, there's someone to help you. The service is great for going through immigration, and then for the suitcases, they help you collect them and place them on a trolley. Thank you for managing this (very clean) welcoming airport

TEXT: There were some good and not so good things about travelling through KL International Airport. Hospitality from all staff I interacted with was good. It was helpful, friendly, and courteous. The airport was also very clean and had a lot of facilities. It is very spacious, which was both positive and negative. It meant that there was plenty of space to sit and relax before the flight and quiet places could be found. On the minus side, it meant a lot of walking to get from place to place, and at times, I found it to be a bit chaotic and disorganised, finding our way around. It was a bit of a longer walk for us to get to the gate. Once there, we hopped on a bus that drove us across the terminal grounds. This took a while, too. Once off the bus, it was another longer walk to the actual gate.

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) A Major Asian Hub with Smooth Connectivity | Travel Consultant Review As a travel consultant, I often recommend KLIA as a transit point or entry to Southeast Asia. Here's a breakdown of the experience: Highlights: Modern Infrastructure KLIA is clean, spacious, and well-designed. The terminalsKLIA (Main Terminal) and KLIA2 (Low-cost Terminal)are efficiently connected via train and shuttle. Connectivity Excellent connectivity via ERL (Express Rail Link) to central Kuala Lumpur in just ~30 minutes. Clear signage in English and Malay makes navigation easy for international travelers. Immigration & Security Immigration can be quick during non-peak hours, but delays are possible during busy times. Security is generally smooth and well-organized. Shopping & Amenities KLIA offers duty-free shops, premium brands, local crafts, and great food courts. Muslim prayer rooms, child play areas, lounges, and clean restrooms add to the comfort. Hospitality & Help Desks Friendly and professional staff. Help counters and digital info kiosks are helpful, especially for first-time visitors. Things to Keep in Mind: KLIA2 is separate and caters mostly to AirAsia and budget carriersplan accordingly if you have a connecting flight between KLIA and KLIA2. Transit times between gates can be long; allow extra time, especially for international connections. Consultants Tip: Use the Plaza Premium Lounge for long layoversits affordable and well-equipped. Download the Malaysia Airports app for real-time updates and gate information. Overall Rating: 8.5/10 A world-class airport that balances efficiency with Malaysian hospitalityideal for smooth international transit or as a gateway to explore Malaysia.

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur international airport was one of the most magnificent airports I have been able to visit. This airport is the main hub to the huge city of Kuala Lumpur. Located almost 50km+ away from the actual city, this absolutely massive airport features numerous runways, and terminals. When we first arrived at the airport, we were relatively lost and confused! After more walking then my previous experiences in MLE, BLR, TRV, COK and CMB (all relatively smaller airports except BLR), we had to board a bus to another building in order to collect our baggage! The terminals itself are a bit well designed. The baggage collection carousels are absolutely humungous. The airport shuttle bus between terminals is a bit cramped though, when you are carrying the carry-on baggage. On the bright side, it does have seats which great. There is more greenery in the terminal than I'd have expected, it is spotless and extremely clean. There is large variety of resturants, other shops and sim/money exchange places (way more expensive than outside of airport). One thing I will highlight is the toilets are magnificent here. Whole other airports I've visited in India also have clean toilets, the hand drying systems aren't as advanced. I had a whale of a time inside the toilets in this airport, and I would rate them 5/5 star, no drama. When we went to the airport for our return flight back home, we saw more of the beautiful views and architecture of the airport. It is more easier to navigate the departures in my opinion. And, I'm sure for most people even arrivals won't be hard to navigate, it had been a while since we had flown anyways. I truly had a whale of a time in Kuala Lumpur international airport and was extremely impressed with the state of the art facilities. It also features KILA train service to the city center (KL Sentral) which is a cheaper alternative to redhing this airport (there quite far from the city). I'd love to visit Malaysia and this airport again in the future. Ps: the jetbridges are so much more convinent when boarding the airplanes! Really like those.

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA)! Get ready for a travel hub that's as bustling as a beehive and as modern as a sci-fi movie set! Imagine a place where you can embark on adventures, connect with people from all corners of the globe, and maybe even find a duty-free bargain or two! Picture yourself navigating the terminals, feeling like you're starring in your own international spy thriller (minus the actual danger, hopefully!), and wondering if you should grab one last cup of Malaysian teh tarik before boarding (spoiler alert: you definitely should!) . You can explore the shops, admire the architecture, and maybe even people-watch while waiting for your flight, feeling like you're witnessing a microcosm of the world! However, lets be honest, sometimes an "international airport" can feel a bit like a real-life game of "dodge the rolling suitcases," where you're trying to navigate the crowds while also trying to avoid getting your toes run over . And while the excitement of travel is undeniable, you might also find yourself questioning your ability to resist the urge to buy all the travel-sized snacks, especially if you're a sucker for a pre-flight treat . Overall, Kuala Lumpur International Airport offers a dynamic and exciting experience, a place where you can start or end your journey, witness the magic of travel, and maybe even find a little bit of inspiration, even if you sometimes feel like youre participating in a synchronized airport-walking marathon with a hundred other jet-setting individuals. Happy travels! Sources and related content

TEXT: Flying out or landing in KLIA2? Heres a quick dose: KLIA2 opened in 2014 to replace the old LCCT (Low-Cost Carrier Terminal)and is now the home base for airlines like AirAsia and is one of the biggest purpose-built low-cost terminals in the world! Yes..so big you can literally walk 2km (I think its more..) inside to get to your boarding gate.so be sure to wear comfy shoes or your best cushioned disco sandals (or bring a scooter?) Gateway@KLIA2 is connected to the terminal, packed with food, stores & even a grocery! Its like a mini shopping mall with gates, to the extent you could arrive with just credit and dress up from top to bottom complete with rolling luggage to rock the day. Flying via KLIA2 makes you an early bird even if you are a marathon runner (kudos to you if you have pre-checked in and zero check in luggage). Get there at least 3 hours earlyimmigration lines can be sneaky long or check into the many aerohotels or capsule hotels (sama-sama) for a place to crash. Enjoy the lounge or play the Malaysian national sportand explore vast culinary from nasi lemak to homeland FuiYoh uncle Rogers fried rice and delicate steamed dumplings from din tai fung or A&W and McDonalds, doze on a massage chair or people watch till you daze if you have plenty of time to kill. Currency exchanges are all around (RHBs rate is not bad) KLIA Ekspres from KL Sentral gets you there fast & comfy. E-hailing is a buzz with tonnes of queues at level 1 Whether youre heading off to new adventures or coming home to Nasi Lemak, KLIA2s got your back.

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is one of the busiest and most modern airports in Southeast Asia. The design is spacious, clean, and well-organized, making it easy to navigate between terminals. Immigration and security are generally efficient, though queues can get long during peak hours. The airport offers a wide range of facilities including lounges, duty-free shopping, dining options from local Malaysian food to international cuisine, and convenient rest areas. Connectivity is excellent, with the KLIA Ekspres train providing a fast and smooth link to the city center. For transit passengers, the airport is comfortable with plenty of seating, free Wi-Fi, and clear signage. The architecture and surrounding greenery also add a calm atmosphere, reflecting Malaysias natural beauty. Overall, KLIA is a well-managed international hub that combines efficiency with hospitality, making it a pleasant gateway to Malaysia.

TEXT: Kuala Lumpur international airport was one of the most magnificent airports I have been able to visit. This airport is the main hub to the huge city of Kuala Lumpur. Located almost 50km+ away from the actual city, this absolutely massive airport features numerous runways, and terminals. When we first arrived at the airport, we were relatively lost and confused! After more walking then my previous experiences in MLE, BLR, TRV, COK and CMB (all relatively smaller airports except BLR), we had to board a bus to another building in order to collect our baggage! The terminals itself are a bit well designed. The baggage collection carousels are absolutely humungous. The airport shuttle bus between terminals is a bit cramped though, when you are carrying the carry-on baggage. On the bright side, it does have seats which great. There is more greenery in the terminal than I'd have expected, it is spotless and extremely clean. There is large variety of resturants, other shops and sim/money exchange places (way more expensive than outside of airport). One thing I will highlight is the toilets are magnificent here. Whole other airports I've visited in India also have clean toilets, the hand drying systems aren't as advanced. I had a whale of a time inside the toilets in this airport, and I would rate them 5/5 star, no drama. When we went to the airport for our return flight back home, we saw more of the beautiful views and architecture of the airport. It is more easier to navigate the departures in my opinion. And, I'm sure for most people even arrivals won't be hard to navigate, it had been a while since we had flown anyways. I truly had a whale of a time in Kuala Lumpur international airport and was extremely impressed with the state of the art facilities. It also features KILA train service to the city center (KL Sentral) which is a cheaper alternative to redhing this airport (there quite far from the city). I'd love to visit Malaysia and this airport again in the future. Ps: the jetbridges are so much more convinent when boarding the airplanes! Really like those.

TEXT: Flying out or landing in KLIA2? Heres a quick dose: KLIA2 opened in 2014 to replace the old LCCT (Low-Cost Carrier Terminal)and is now the home base for airlines like AirAsia and is one of the biggest purpose-built low-cost terminals in the world! Yes..so big you can literally walk 2km (I think its more..) inside to get to your boarding gate.so be sure to wear comfy shoes or your best cushioned disco sandals (or bring a scooter?) Gateway@KLIA2 is connected to the terminal, packed with food, stores & even a grocery! Its like a mini shopping mall with gates, to the extent you could arrive with just credit and dress up from top to bottom complete with rolling luggage to rock the day. Flying via KLIA2 makes you an early bird even if you are a marathon runner (kudos to you if you have pre-checked in and zero check in luggage). Get there at least 3 hours earlyimmigration lines can be sneaky long or check into the many aerohotels or capsule hotels (sama-sama) for a place to crash. Enjoy the lounge or play the Malaysian national sportand explore vast culinary from nasi lemak to homeland FuiYoh uncle Rogers fried rice and delicate steamed dumplings from din tai fung or A&W and McDonalds, doze on a massage chair or people watch till you daze if you have plenty of time to kill. Currency exchanges are all around (RHBs rate is not bad) KLIA Ekspres from KL Sentral gets you there fast & comfy. E-hailing is a buzz with tonnes of queues at level 1 Whether youre heading off to new adventures or coming home to Nasi Lemak, KLIA2s got your back.

TEXT: Modern, well-connected, and spacious international airport Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is one of Southeast Asias most impressive airports. Its clean, well-organized, and offers plenty of services for both international and domestic travelers. The airport is split into two terminals: KLIA (main terminal) for full-service airlines and KLIA2 for budget carriers like AirAsia. A free shuttle bus runs between them frequently, which is super convenient. The main terminal (KLIA) is spacious with high ceilings and even includes a small indoor rainforesta really unique touch! Immigration and customs can be slow during peak hours, but the staff are generally friendly and helpful. Signage throughout the airport is clear, and its easy to find your way around. KLIA2 is more modern in terms of retail options, offering a wide variety of shops, restaurants, and lounges. It has more of a shopping mall feel and is perfect if you have a long layover. However, walking distances can be long, so plan accordingly. The KLIA Ekspres train makes travel to and from downtown Kuala Lumpur quick and easy (about 30 minutes), which is a major plus. Some downsides include occasional delays at immigration and certain gates that require shuttle buses, which isnt ideal for tired travelers. Still, overall, KLIA is a great airportefficient, comfortable, and a solid first impression of Malaysia.
